dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LITTLE JIMMY DICKENS’ plays "Country Boy". We see FARMERS OIL WELLS, RAILROAD TRACKS in a dusty landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON HASKINS, a tall, Oklahoma boy, 18, dresses into a bad rental tuxedo for the prom, admiring the velveteen lapels

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A “WHITES ONLY" drinking fountain. A sign reads: "You Bre It, We'll Feed It!". HERMAN CARR, 18, handsome, black, unloads grain bags as CONVERTIBLES barrel past with laugh white HIGH SCHOOL PROM KIDS. He watches with yearning. Th store's owner comes out. Carr quickly turns back to his w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEENS dance to COUNTRY MUSIC. A line at the GIRLS ROOM. M GORMAN, 17 and pretty, comes out and goes to the punch bo looking for someone. We hear a BOUNCING BASKETBALL. She m to a CURTAIN dividing the auditorium and peeks BEHIND IT. ON THE OTHER SIDE: Don Haskins obsessively drills free th into a hoop. She rolls her eyes and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don Haskins! Come on. Dance with me. LATER ON THE DANCE FLOOR... Haskins and Mary dance togeth

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (heavy Oklahoma drawl) I’m sure havin’ a good time, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Me, too, Don.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Did I tell you I got accepted to A&M?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just about ten times tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Guess I’m just excited.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh, it‘ll be nice for you. Goin’ off to college. Much as you love to play basketball. Sometimes I think there’s nothing you love more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mary, I-- I love you... too... Fact is, there’s somethin’ I’m wantin’ to ask a long time now-- and I don't always say things right-- but Mary, you're my girl. I want to spend my life with you-- Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (a slow beaming smile) Guess I'll take second place-- for now. He picks her up and twirls her in the air on the dance fl EXT. ENID FEED AND GRAIN - LOADING AREA — NEXT DAY Haskins and Carr play basketball behind the store.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Brother, you fall hard. But-- Mary’s a nice girl. She'll make you a good wife.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. Come on. Last point. Carr lifts off with breathtaking agility. The BALL floats through the net. Haskins groans. Carr grins back.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: You hate to lose, man.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don’t hate to lose, I just like to win. My Daddy always drummed it into me. ‘You play to win’.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: (looks at basket; thoughtful) You ever get that feeling when you're playing?-- That feeling like you're moving like Sam Cooke sings. Sounds funny, but when I play-- I feel like that.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Sam Cooke? Is he from Enid?

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Brother, you one Okie.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well, make fun, but I ain't never felt like that. But I reckon’ I don't play like you neither. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASKINS (cont'd) I sure’ll be glad when I can play with you not against your skinny butt. Did you get your letter yet from A&M? CARR. We ain’t gonna be playin’ together.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: I got my letter. They don't play black folk. Told me to stay home and work my job.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: They can’t do that! You’re the best player in the state!

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Guess that don’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well-- if you ain’t goin’ neither am I!

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Stop talkin’ like a fool, man! Playin’ basketball's your life. You better be goin’! At least-- at least one of us--...

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (pained for him) What are you gonna do now, Herman?

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: I’1l be alright. You know. That's just how it goes. Wasn't my time.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: But it just ain’t right. Wish there was somethin’ I could do.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Play for me, Don. You make it big, alright? You go all the way, Don. Don nods. Carr pulls him in, emotional. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I better go now. Carr nods, tight. Don turns to his car. He gets in and st the engine. Carr comes out as Don pulls away. Don looks i the mirror and sees Carr on the sidewalk, broom in hand, to the "Whites Only" drinking fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is in the stands, cradling a newborn. She watches Ha sink a shot. The crowd goes wild. The opposition loses th ball and Haskins goes after it fiercely, COLLIDING with a TEXAS player. The crowd rises as Haskins FALLS BACK, hitt on his elbow. Mary gasps. Don lies writhing, clasping his

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: Don drives to BUCK OWENS and ROSE MADDOX'S "Mental Cruelt Mary holds a NEW BABY in her arms. Their FIRST SON bounce the back as they pass a sign: "BENJAMIN, TEXAS. POP 250."

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: It'll be great, honey! I'll coach. We'll have a house with a yard for the kids! They'll even let me drive the bus to make ends meet! Honey, it'll be paradise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins exhorts the BENJAMIN GIRL'S TEAM playing the DEFE STATE CHAMPS. The clock runs down as the crowd, cheers.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Winnaker! Get on Robinson! Play the ball! What are you doin' out there! You're not stickin' to your man. What are you, a bunch of girls? Come on, hustle! IN THE CROWD. GEORGE MCCARTY, a COLLEGIATE ATHLETIC DIREC sits watching Haskins with interest. The BUZZER SOUNDS. The girls leap in the air. Swarming ar Haskins, they try to LIFT the big man on their shoulders, quickly collapse under his weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROPHIES LINE A SHELF. Don watches TV. On screen is a NCA GAME: ADOLPH RUPP, the legendary coach of the “Kentucky Wildcats”, plays an arena full of screaming fans.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The ‘Baron of the Bluegrass‘, Adolph Rupp, does it again! Winning the Southern Conference berth and returning to the NCAA Tournament for the thirtieth time. The question now is: can Rupp, the greatest coach in the game, win an unprecedented fifth National Championship? Haskins flicks off the TV, moody as Mary enters.  HASKINS. There's gotta be more than this, Mary. More than Benjamin, Texas.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Always restless. Always gotta have better. You got a family now. You’re a winning coach. Is that so bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TELEVISION we see young BILL COSBY and ROBERT CULP gun toting partners in the “I Spy” series. THROUGH THE WI OUTSIDE... Don is coaching his three year old son, MARK.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Come on! I pass, you catch and put it up! Don zips a ridiculous pass at Mark. It bounces off his ch

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Catch it with your hands-- not your arms! Mark's lips quiver and he cries. Haskins tries to console as Mary comes and takes him, flashing a look. Haskins goe and stops at the TV as the old crank PHONE on the wall RI He picks up as we hear a VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Ray at Texas Western University. We'd like to speak to you about an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RAY, college president, sits with George McCarty, the University’s Athletic Director, facing a neatly combed Ha

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: I’m pleased to hear you're interested in the coaching job, Mr. Haskins. The Texas Athletic Association recommended we take a look at you. McCarty here caught your last championship game. He says you’re a winner.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I sure ‘preciate that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: We're a small school and we can’t pay very much. You'd have to live in the men's dorm with your family. But you get free meals at the cafeteria. How’s that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that’s what it takes to coach Division One basketball, that’s alright with me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand; smile) Welcome to Texas Western. INT. DON’S BUICK - MOVING ~ TEXAS INTERSTATE - DAY Mary holds a NEW BABY. TWO SONS in back. They tow a cattl truck of their belongings to MARTY ROBBINS’ "El Paso". Th town sprawls out in the middle of vast, desolate nothingn

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Baby, this is a step up. It’s college basketball! We’re in the big time now. EXT. TEXAS WESTERN CAMPUS - OUTSIDE MINERS DORMS -— DAY Families drop off their kids with suitcases and hugs and tears as Don's Buick pulls up. Haskins gets out. A dark haired boy, JERRY ARMSTRONG, stands with his FATHER, a ha farming type.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG FATHER
dialogues.text: How long you gonna waste your time, boy? Playin’ a kids game when you got your whole future right there on the farn.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I made up my mind, Pa. It’s what I wanna do. Don notes it and walks ahead when he hears a WHISTLE and Mary is surrounded by kids and suitcases. He turns, sheep

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Sorry, baby. Guess I’m just excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROWDY STUDENTS run past. Don walks with MOE “SQUEAKY” IBA a very short, earnest ASSISTANT COACH with horn-rimmed gl His voice is high, hence the unfortunate nickname.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: We're clearing out our best rooms for you, Mr. Haskins. I think you and your family are gonna like it. He opens a door to a room full of taxidermy and fishing g An alligator hangs from the ceiling. ROSS MOORE, TEAM TRAINER, 65, stands in his underwear: a grinning Cajun with crew cut.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: This is Ross Moore. Our team trainer. He's movin’ to a smaller room down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I hate to put you out--

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Don't you worry a thing. I'm even willing to lend you my prize gator here. Makes a real nice ceiling ornament.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (eyeing the snarling gator) That's real kind of you, Ross. But the wife doesn’t take to wildlife too much. But I thank you. I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands with her baby as GUADALUPE, a domestic from Juarez, is warming milk, smiling at the baby.

dialogues.speaker: GUADALUPE
dialogues.text: Que carinfo. Can I hold him? Guadalupe radiates so much warmth, that Mary hands her th baby. Guadalupe coos with the boy. Mary smiles, happy. INT. “MEMORIAL GYM” - TEXAS WESTERN - NEXT DAY Moe walks with Don into Memorial Gym. A bunch of short, s white guys pass the ball around.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Got some good players. Signed Baudoin outta Albuquerque. Put up twenty a game last year. Got us a strong farm boy outta Missouri, too. Kid named Armstrong. The gym has worn seats, loose boards, crooked rims, threa nets. Lights buzz and flicker. Hardly a place of champion

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: David Palacio’s top prep scorer in El Paso. Still waitin’ on some junior college transfers. And on Taco Night-- we get a real good crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taco night? My girls had better moves than these kids. What's in the budget for recruiting?

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: The budget’s in the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don stands across from McCarty, the Athletic Director. INT/EXT.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: How in Sam-hell can I put a winning team on the floor when I got no players and no budget to get them?

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTY
dialogues.text: I could shake down a few more bucks from the boosters. Get a couple scholarships.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: A few bucks?! I can’t go recruit with one or two scholarships.

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTY
dialogues.text: Don, you know damn well we ain't Kansas, Duke, Kentucky. We’re a poor school. We can't afford blue chip players, and they wouldn't want to play in this dusty-ass town even if we could. Reality is, we're lucky to put a decent team on the court.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well, decent ain’t good enough for me. I play to win.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF IMAGES
dialogues.text: Don drives by the Rio Grande; through night time streets; the top of Mt. Franklin; staring out, discontent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don stands by his car in a jacket with “Miners” logo. TWO WHITE and HISPANIC, look at him from their pick-up truck.

dialogues.speaker: HISPANIC FAN
dialogues.text: Hey, you’re the new coach. Gonna get us some wins this year?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’1l do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, man. You’re gonna need it. Don nods, depressed. They laugh and drive off. EXT. DON’S BUICK ~- DRIVING - EL PASO - LATER THAT NIGHT Don stops as something catches his eye: A BLACK TEENAGER basketball court. Don watches the boy LIFT into the air a soar SKYWARD. We FLASH to the IMAGE OF HERMAN CARR cleari the rim. As Carr JAMS the ball into the hoop, Haskins wat the boy lay the ball off the board in a silky motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTIN LUTHER KING is seen on a TELEVISION, as he speaks RALLY IN D.C.. Haskins sits with Moe and Ross at a table.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: You're beatin’ a dead horse, Coach. We're never gonna compete with the Kentucky’s of the world.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Best players won't even look at us.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Best white players, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS.
dialogues.text: Say that again, Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Best players aren’t all white. (looks around at them) What if we find us the best black talent in the country and bring 'em here?

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: You got to be joking. Why would you wanna go do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don’t care what color anybody is, black, white, green. If they can play, they can play for me.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: How many are you talkin’ about?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: As many as we can get.  10.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Coach. There are rules. Unwritten rules. You know the quotas. ‘One at home. Two on the road. Three when you're losing.’ But loading up on Negroes-- it just isn't done.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Who cares about rules? Rules are meant to be broken.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Now you listen, Sonny. You bring in a bunch of colored boys-- you risk the whole program.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid of risks. I’m not afraid to gamble. Not if it means winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP: BOBBY JOE HILL, a black kid from Detroit with a fancy conk, leans back on a sideline bench in the middle noisy Junior College Nationals game, DOZING, HALF~ASLEEP. ON THE FLOOR... all the PLAYERS are white. They play supe conservative, pass and set-shot ball of the day. IN THE STANDS... Don sits with Moe and Ross.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Three days, nine games, and you ain’t liked nobody yet.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’m waitin’ on that guard.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: That kid? He looks asleep!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: ‘Cause nobody’s playin’ him. ON COURT... the team is being destroyed. The COACH gruffl shakes Bobby Joe awake and signals him into the game. Bobby Joe, once awake, has intelligent, playful eyes and cocky demeanor. He quickly takes the court. Immediately t game changes. Lightning quick, he finds openings where th aren't any, dribbles past players with dazzling speed.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's the one. Let’s us go talk to him.  ll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands with a beer-belly Redneck TOURNAMENT DIREC

dialogues.speaker: TOURNAMENT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: You wanna talk to Bobby Joe Hill? You can't win playin' ‘nigger ball. Can't control ‘em. Sure they can jump like goddamn monkeys. But they can’t lead. That boy in particular. He’s just a no- account smart ass. Showboatin' like a globetrotter clown.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Just tell me where to find him.

dialogues.speaker: TOURNAMENT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Y'all must be real hard up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe Hill is clearing his locker. Don walks up with and Ross. Bobby Joe sees them, wary.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’m Coach Haskins. I wanna talk to you about playing for me at Texas Western.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Thanks but-- I’m done playin’ this game.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’m offerin’ a full scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I know how that works. You sign me and sit your token Negro on the bench. I'd rather hang it up, do somethin’ else. Ace. Be the next Smokey Robinson. Or I could run for president.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I watched you out there. You got somethin’ special. Why would you throw it away?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Because ever since I was a kid I only loved one thing and that was playin’ ball. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY JOE (cont'd) But being a black mascot, ridin’ the bench like some Stepin’ Fetchit ass lawn jockey while White brothers with half my game get the glory may be good enough for most brothers, but not for Bobby Joe Hill, not anymore. I‘1l walk away from the game rather than play that shit. He grabs his duffle bag and walks out of the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins follows Hill, trying to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I didn’t come here to sit you on the bench. I intend to let you play. Play with other black men.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What are you smokin’, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I ain’t smokin’ nuthin’, Bubba. Now you just told me about a big ol’ dream you have. I can let you play, and I can help you make that dream come true faster than a twister’ll take your socks off.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You know, you talk funny.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What’s this team anyway?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: The Miners.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I never even heard of them. They any good?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You can help make them good.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Are you for real, man?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (holding up the papers) Try me.  13. EXT. DON’S BUICK - DRIVING TENNESSEE FREEWAY - DUSK A long stretch of highway in the setting sun. Don‘s Buick seen from way on high OVER BOBBY FULLER'S “I Fought The L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CONTINUES on JUKE BOX. Ross on a pay phone. Don wat GOOD 01’ BOYS shoot pool. Moe flips through scouting repo

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Okay. According to the scouts, here’s who we need to see. Harry Flournoy. Indiana. Great rebounder in high school. Gave it up to work in the steel mills. Orsten “Little O” Artis. Can shoot the lights out. Lot of schools want him. David Lattin. He’s a long shot. Down in Houston. They say he’s a hot head, but he’s one of the top big men in the country. Everybody says he’s leaning to Tennessee A@I, the all black school.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We'll get him. We have to get him.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: And how we gonna do that? We ain’t even got enough gas money to get home. Ross hangs up the phone and sits down, excited.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I got through to Hilton White in New York. He’s got three kids we should look at. Now they’re just playground kids, but Hilton knows talent and he says they can play with anybody.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Moe, you're on the first flight out.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: You’re sendin’ me to New York for some school yard players?! Who’s payin’ for all this? You gotta be outta your mind.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Bubba, I’m just gettin’ started. Haskins grabs a pool cue and puts a quarter on the pool t  14.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Ya'll mind if I give it a run, fellas? GOOD OL’ BOY We play for real money here, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good ol’ boy lays a C-NOTE down, grinning. Ross and M watch Haskins empties his pockets to the last quarter.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What the hell you doin’, Coach?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Just layin’ down the corn... The good ol’ boy sinks quick shots, rimming out of the co pocket. Then Haskins runs the table, down to the eight ba The good ol’ boy’s speechless. Haskins takes the C Note.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: There's one rule in pool, boys. Don’t play with amputees or strangers. (tossing the money) Here’s your plane fare, Squeaky. INT. DON’S BUICK - DRIVING ON FREEWAY - DAY Don and Ross driving. Ross sings to BIG BILL LISTER “Ther A Tear In My Beer” at the top of his voice, annoying Hask

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins and Ross in the car, watch TWO BLACK WORKERS from mill, play one-on-one on concrete with a hoop and no net. HARRY FLOURNOY, tall, powerful, slams in a basket-rattlin two. His FRIEND grins, shaking his head. They rap hands.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK FRIEND
dialogues.text: You comin’ over? I got the new Otis Redding. That cat’s on fire, man.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Dig, man, but I can’t stay long. Mama baked some pie. There's only one piece left and I been thinking about it all day.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, kid-- you have a minute? Don pulls up, COUNTRY MUSIC blaring.  15.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: We don’t want no trouble, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: No, you don't understand, just get in the car and we can--

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Like hell, I’m gettin’ in no car with a couple’a crackers! Haskins stops the car. Flournoy looks at his friend. On c they both run. Haskins watches them, and drives ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry enters through the back door and flings his factory down. His MOTHER carries a tray of coffee to the next roo

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Hey, Ma. You won't believe happened to me and Alvin. Almost got jumped by a couple of red-necked crackers. (looking around) I'm just dying for that piece of pie. Mrs. Flournoy enters the living room with Flournoy follow He stops, shocked, when he sees HASKINS sitting at a tabl next to Flournoy's FATHER, eating his PIECE OF BLUEBERRY

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Ma‘am, this is plumb delicious-- Mrs. Flournoy pushes her speechless son into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Haskins. He come all the way from El Paso, Texas. Wants you to play basketball for him on a scholarship!

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Play for him? Why would I go to Texas where they soon as string up black men as set off Fourth of July fireworks? FLOURNOY’S FATHER Harry's got a good job right here in Gary. At the factory. With me.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: But he can get himself an education.  16.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: And a Texas-sized beating for being black.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: El Paso’s not like the rest of Texas. We do things different. You'll be playing with other black players.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Why should I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I mean what I say. There is a tense silence. Flournoy glares at Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You ate my pie. Haskins leans in close.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Harry, forget about me or your parents. What is it that you really want?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: What anybody wants. Dignity. Respect.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's what this is all about. You can earn that for yourself by doing what you were born to do. Haskins slides the commitment papers across the table.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Papa?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: They're right, Harry. You have a chance to follow your dream. Don’t let it go. Flournoy looks at his father with emotion and signs the p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins’ car pulls up in front of the YMCA and parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ORSTEN ARTIS, a good looking player, with a smooth, easy sinks a shot with A BEVY OF GIRLS swooning. Haskins besid  17.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: I got lots of offers. But I just made up my mind to play with the Globetrotters.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: And act the fool with your talent? What I‘m offering you is better. I can make you a champion.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I never joke about winning. Haskins lays a letter of intent on the free throw line.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Tell you what. I’m not really a gamblin’ man, but-- how ‘bout we shoot for it. Best of twenty. You win and I'm outta here. I win-- you play for me.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: You want to take me on?!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's the general idea.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Let’s do it. Orsten shoots as his friends count along. He misses THE L SHOT and tosses the ball to Haskins, cocky.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: It's all yours, cowboy. Haskins first shot rims and drops in. Orsten and friends expressions change as Haskins drills shot after shot. Orsten’s mouth is agape as the last shot slithers through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don's Buick barrels into frame and disappears down the highway. We hear TAMMY WYNETTE’S “My Elusive Dreams”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe stands at a phone booth, while THREE BLACK PLAYERS bl past in the background, shooting baskets with amazing ski  18.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: These New York kids may be from the street but they sure can play! Little guard plays like he's a giant. Forward who runs like an antelope. A swing man who can play anywhere! Never seen anything like ‘em!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When can you have them out?

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Week maybe. How’s it going with Lattin? We got to have a big man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don stands, one hand covering his ear from traffic noise.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: The odds are long, but I got one more roll in these dice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins sits with A&I’s BLACK COACH. Beside him is DAVID huge, powerful, with shaved head and intimidating self~as

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: David, this is a good school and they give lots of players a chance they wouldn’t get somewhere else. But it’s still just the black league. You’re not out there being tested in the real world. David, the way you play, you could be the next Bill Russell. But you'll never know unless you play NCAA competition and win. And frankly that means playing the best white centers in the country and beating them.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: I can beat any honky ass white boy. Big Daddy D can play with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Then prove it. Sign with me.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: How's he gonna play anybody at all at Texas Western? A red neck town with a team that’s never won? We know that game. You’1l take David and make him ride the bench like any plantation nigger.  19.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: You think I could be the next Bill Russell?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You play for me and I promise you'll get that chance.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: (looking torn) You're too late. I already made up my mind. I'm signing with Tennessee. The coach smiles at Haskins, smug. Haskins finally nods.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: So that's how it is, huh? You’re better than this, David. You change your mind, you call me, you hear? Just call.

dialogues.speaker: EL PASO
dialogues.text: Ross drives the NEW YORK PLAYERS and Moe. WILLIE WORSLEY, short, urbanite, militant, with a “Napoleon complex” sits next to Moe who is eyeing Worsley’s HIGH HEELED BOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: What you lookin’ at? I sky with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: I know that, Willie. IN THE BACK ROW is WILLIE “SCOOPS” CAGER, a lanky player a cocky attitude and a good heart. His childhood friend a protege, NEVIL SHED, a tall, skinny “mama's boy” beside h They pass tumbleweeds and the waterless Rio Grande.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: This don’t exactly look like them Lone Ranger movies. You know, with them rollin’ hills and big ass prairies.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Where the hell's this Coach bringin’ us?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: El Paso, Texas. God’s country.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: If this is God’s country, good Lord must be mad at somethin’.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: There ain't no place like El Paso. Beautiful West Texas sunlight three hundred and thirty days a year. It’s ‘bout heaven on earth. They almost believe him. Then a pick-up truck full of ROO swerves ahead. Chickens fly over the van as Ross curses something Cajun. The players are jolted back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE WHITE PLAYERS look into the cafeteria through a wind the door: JERRY ARMSTRONG, the farm boy we saw with his f DICK MYERS, a tall, clean cut Kansan, DAVID PALACIO, a to proud Hispanic with a gold cross around his neck, LOUIS “ BAUDOIN, a prankster with buzz cut and horn rimmed glasse TOGO RAILEY, a skinny kid who brings more enthusiasm than

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: Well, look who's just come to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Those our new team mates?

dialogues.speaker: MYERS
dialogues.text: There’s more blacks than us whites! How’s he gonna play all them players?

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: You think Coach knows what he’s doing?

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: He said things were gonna be different this year. Guess he wasn’t kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevil Shed waits in line, towering over Willie Worsley.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Don’t that smell good? I can't wait to eat me a whole tray full of food. This big ol’ boy's starvin'! MEANWHILE... THE BLACK RECRUITS sit at one end of a table while the WHITE PLAYERS sit at the other end. They nod a silent greeting. There is an awkward silence and tense sm

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Where you brothers from, man?  21.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Missoura. Dick here's from Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Wow. So you guys had cows, chickens and pigs and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MYERS
dialogues.text: Armstrong's the farm boy. We just had some sheep, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You got animals where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: In New York City they got all kinda animals. Most of them talk though. CAFETERIA LINE... Shed looks at the Mexican dishes, confu

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: You said it was-- what?!

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN SERVER
dialogues.text: Menudo. Muy bueno.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I never even heard of that. AT THE TABLE... Togo smiles at the wary Flournoy.

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: So-- you from Harlem or whatever?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You think all blacks are from Harlem?!

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: Take it easy, cabron. He didn’t mean nothing.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Yeah? And so where you from?

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: From right here. El Paso, Texas.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Really? I thought all you people were from Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Peace, man. Brothers, peace.  22.

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: I'm from New Mexico. That‘’s not even considered America. He smiles. Flournoy doesn't smile back. CAFETERIA LINE... The server hands Shed a plate of enchil

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN SERVER
dialogues.text: Rojo es bueno, si. Muy caliente.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: (enunciating clearly) Thank you. Thank you very much. AT THE TABLE... Shed drops his tray down, rubbing his han

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: This Negro is ready to eat ala Mexicana! Shed scoops a mouthful of chile smothered enchilada. Bloo runs from his face. He lets out an 'I'm on fire' SCREAM a douses his mouth in water as the others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don studies diagrams in playbooks as his sons, Mark and Michael clumsily demonstrate juggling tricks with oranges

dialogues.speaker: BOYS
dialogues.text: Look, Daddy, look, look, Daddy, look!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go on, boys. Time for bed. Daddy's got work to do. The boys walk out, heads hanging. Just then loud MUSIC ri from the street. Haskins looks out, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels of a green Plymouth Fury convertible roll into frame. As the car approaches, a crowd forms around it. IN THE BACKSEAT there are speakers wired to the stereo wi THE ROLLING STONES “Get Off Of My Cloud” playing. THE CAR stops. Door opens and a pair of WHITE SHOES steps Cager, Worsley, and Orsten come to the front, gaping.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Qooh, Mama, look at them wheels!  23.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: That brother is stylin'. ANGLE ON: DAVID LATTIN with shaved head, green silk shirt Ray Bans, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: That is one bad ass car.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: That is one bad ass man. Haskins comes walking outside, looking speechless.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: David?... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: I'm the best. I came to be the best. Haskins looks back at him a moment. He slowly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Welcome to El Paso, David. They shake hands. The others gather and slap him on the b Worsley has his hand outheld for a shake. Lattin drops hi suitcase in Worsley’s hand and walks off. Worsley frowns.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Mercy Jesus, we in for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross leads some of the black players across campus.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Straight ahead is the gym, fellas. Shed and Cager follow. As they pass a MARIACHI BAND, practicing with guitars and violin. Shed looks at Cager.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Willie, we still in America?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsten and Worsley pass by friendly, smiling students in cowboy hats. They glance back at them, non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe comes down as two GIRLS smile at him.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Groovy. You play for the Miners?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I didn’t know they played Negros.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: If they don't, I took the wrong plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black players are dressing. A HISPANIC JANITOR comes

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: You the new players?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: The mighty Miners.

dialogues.speaker: JANITOR
dialogues.text: Mighty Miners?! This team ain’t had a winning season since Pearl Harbor! Mighty Miners. That’s funny. He walks out, chuckling. The players look at each other g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players follow Ross into the rickety gym dressed in g Russell t-shirts with orange shorts. They look around.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: This is it. This is the place. Your new home. You boys have no idea kinda things gonna happen around here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m worried about, bro. Ross opens the door of COACH’S OFFICE. The players look i and see the trophies above Haskins’ desk, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We got lucky findin’ Coach Haskins. He won state last year, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Yeah, man? No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Had those gals playin’ so tough, nobody could stop ‘em.  The players stare at the photos next to the trophies. each, Don stands smiling with the “Benjamin Eight” gi

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You tellin’ us the man coached a girls team? A high school girls team?!

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You bet. He’s a winner. The players look at each other, bleak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins walks before the assembled players. He stops Lattin, who is wearing his sunglasses. Haskins leans

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Lose the shades, Lattin. Reluctant, Lattin takes off his sunglasses. Shed snic Lattin gives him a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: In three months the 1965 Miners take the floor for the first time. This season won't be like any other before it, because you aren’t like any other team. You will face challenges nobody else will face. The mountain will be higher, the rewards greater. (pacing in front of them) You are here for one reason and that is to play the best basketball that you can-- and to win. (eyes boring into each player) Getting there ain’t gonna be easy. I don’t wanna hear the words ‘can’t’ or ‘won't’ or ‘Mommy’. When you play for me, you play basketball my way. And my way is hard.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Unless your point guard got herself a nice The players chuckle. Haskins flashes a withering smil

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's funny, Bobby Joe. That really is. But I guarantee after one work out with those girls everyone here would be crawlin’ the floor with your tongues a-hangin’. (moving among the players) (MORE )

In rls. at in. kers and rack. e.  26. HASKINS (cont'd) Now you follow my rules. That means discipline on and off the court. No booze, no girls, just fundamental basketball. Haskins’ expression shifts into a new, quiet seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Do your best, push yourself beyond where you ever thought you could go, and I guarantee-- people are gonna be hearin’ from Texas Western. Let's get to it. SERIES OF IMAGES. Haskins BARKS OUT commands military sty as the players sprint the floor, groaning and sweating. LATER: Bobby Joe steals a pass, dribbles through his legs makes a huge shot. Haskins calls him over and gets in his

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Jest playin' my game, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well, that’s street ball and street ball is not what we play here! You don’t dribble between your legs. You don’t go above the rim. And you don’t fish for steals. You miss that pick your team is four on five and that’s two for the enemy. So leave the street ball for the streets! LATER: Players pair up at the basket. Cager goes up again Orsten and makes a huge play, with huge physical effort.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Way to put the effort in, Cager! Shed covers Lattin. Shed is faster, but Lattin more power

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Get out my way, Gumby. You in my office! Shed backs off scared. Lattin slams and rattles the backb Shed struts away, trying to disappear.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Shed?! What was that?! We don’t back down here! Ever!-- And Lattin? Stay in front of the basket. No flushing.  27.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: (high-fiving Lattin) Nice shot, big man. Lattin doesn't slap him back, turning away, mute and angr

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: ‘'Scuse me, Wilt. LATER: Flournoy goes up for the J. Armstrong blocks it an crashes onto Flournoy, knocking him down. Flournoy leaps eyes flashing, and shoves the white player backward.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Take your white hands off me, Farm Boy!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Back off, I didn’t do nothin’! Flournoy lunges back at Armstrong, and they begin to figh but Haskins grabs Flournoy and Armstrong’s jersey and pul them close, face in their faces, lifting them off the gro

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Next person opens his mouth is outta here. Flournoy. Is there a problem Flournoy?!

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I didn't HEAR you, Flournoy!

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: NO! No, Sir!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That goes for all of you. Anymore of that shit and I’m on you faster than a rat on a cheeto. We're a team! And we're gonna act like one! Got me? Now get back to work. Haskins drops them both and walks off. Shed whistles.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: That man is a bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins walks down the hall as Dr. Ray comes up.  28.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: You signed some colored boys, Don. Seven, ain’t that right?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's right. Got some talent.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: That's a lot of-- ‘talent’. I’m not sure how our boosters are gonna take it, Don. This is a little different than what they're used to.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You just let me coach, Dr.. I'll let you handle the boosters. How ‘bout that? He claps him on the shoulder. Dr. Ray watches him go, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myers is dressing next to Baudoin who is washing his face

dialogues.speaker: MYERS
dialogues.text: Coach ran us so hard, I thought I was gonna be sick. Baudoin grins and lies down on the bench and moans in moc illness. Togo puts on Baudoin’s “Clark Kent” glasses.

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: Aha! An acute case of dehydration! He pumps Baudoin’s leg like a pump handle. Baudoin squirt water from his mouth in a high arc, dousing Myers and Pal who YELL OUT. The other guys laugh. Flournoy turns away.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: White boys havin’ fun.

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: Not everybody‘s funny as you two vatos. Flournoy stops and glares. He looks at Lattin.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Back me up, brother. This dude says we ain’t funny. (when Lattin turns; arrogant) Brother, you think you some kinda bad ass?!  29. IN THE SHOWERS... Players shower, bodies sagging. The spi spray water and soap together. Worsley pushes Shed playfu

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: You looked like Lattin's shadow out there, Shed. Big guy like you, afraid?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: How would you know if I’m afraid? All you see is my knee caps.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: You callin’ me short?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Dig, I don’t even need to. Worsley shoves up against Shed, but it makes him slip on soapy water and he disappears from frame. The others laug

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Hey. Any of you guys seen the soap?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: It's comin' right at you, man.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Jeez, soap comin’ out of the walls! How do they do that?! We got nothin' like that in Eagleville!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You in the big time now, Farm Boy. INT. LATTIN’S DORM ROOM - LATER THAT DAY David Lattin is nailing “girlie” posters over his bed, an ROW OF PANTIES on the wall with NAME TAGS: “Yolanda, Cher Dee Dee”. Shed leaves the room, rolling his eyes. INT. CAGER’S ROOM - SAME TIME Cager is dressing at the mirror, lip syncing into his hai to THE SUPREMES “Stop In The Name Of Love” on a radio. INT. FLOURNOY AND WORSLEY’S ROOM ~- SAME TIME Flournoy stares at the poster over Worsley’s bed: a black raising his fist, “Power To The People”. Flournoy picks u the book on his bed. ELDRIDGE CLEAVER'S “Soul On Ice”. Th bathroom door opens. Worsley comes out. Grabs his book ba  30.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t touch my stuff, brother. Leave that to the big boys. You probably ain’t even heard about the Panthers back in Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Man, I know about ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: It’s one thing to know about ‘em. (making a fist in his face) And it’s another to live the life.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I don’t need book to live the life-- brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RANCHERA BAND plays on a small stage. Shed, Orsten, Bob Joe, Cager, Flournoy and Worsley sit waiting for their or

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Coach is one crazy white man. You'd think we was up for a National Championship instead of playin’ on some bush league team.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna be alive for no national nothin' if he keeps workin' us like that.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: They all talk like that in Oklahoma?

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: It ain't even a civilized state.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Who cares where he’s from. Doesn’t mean he don't know what he’s doin’. Maybe he’s right. Maybe people will hear from us someday.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You kiddin’ me? Look at this place. We're in the middle of nowhere, playin’ for a nowhere team. We ain’t got a chance in hell.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: You got a chance. We all do. We can get an education. Only thing that matters anyway. It ain’t basketball that’s gonna make the future for any of us.  31. A platter of tacos arrives. Shed and the others stare.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Brothers. When you’re in a foreign country, you got to respect the customs. They pick up knife and fork and delicately slice the taco

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Hey, where's Lattin tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I dunno. That is one big, mean Negro. He's probably out eatin’ babies.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I say we cross the bridge tonight. I hear Juarez jumps. The tequila's cheap and so are the ladies. Fine lookin’ ladies.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: What you gonna do when you find ‘em, fool? You don't speak no espafiol.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe Hill speaks the universal language-- the language of love.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: What about Coach? He set the rules.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Brother, can’t let the rules cramp your style, know what I’m sayin’? INT. “BODEGA EXCELSIOR” CLUB - JUAREZ, MX - LATER THAT NI Bobby Joe checks his conk as Shed, Cager, Orsten, Worsley Flournoy follow him in. Inside there is SHOUTING, LAUGHTE MARIACHIS WAILING canciones. They take a table in the mid People turn and stare. The room falls SILENT. The players nervous. A gruff BARTENDER comes up, wiping his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Forget it. They don’t want us here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Mezcal for the table. The bartender nods and leaves. Slowly the music begins ag  32.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: What if Coach finds out? We ain't supposed to be here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Relax, Shadow. You worry too much. The bartender returns with a huge bottle of tequila, five shot glasses, limes and a bowie knife and salt shaker.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Aw hell, Bobby Joe. You ordered fruit. The bartender gestures to cut the limes, salt the hand an lick.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: What’s he sayin’?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Could be some kinda Mexican voodoo thing? TWO SENIORITAS squeeze next to Worsley and Orsten and gui them to cut the limes, salt their hands, lick and drink. Orsten’s eyes widen with the sour. The girls giggle.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: That’s some nasty shit, man.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Hell, I'll try it. Shed shakes his head, as Worsley and Cager try it. Bobby holds out a glass to Flournoy. He shakes his head, dour.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Man, is there anything you don’t take too seriously? You gotta lighten up, man. Flournoy glares a moment. Then he takes the glass and kno it back. The other guys hoot and clap. Flournoy risks a s Bobby Joe turns and sees a beautiful, dark skinned senior walking past with a tray of margaritas. He flashes a smil

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby. What's your nombre? She looks back at him, with a confused smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You probably don’t understand a word I’m sayin’ to you, huh? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY JOE (cont'd) Well, that’s good cause what I want from you, baby, you probably ain’t got on the menu. Her look suddenly changes and she speaks perfect English.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You bet your black ass I don’t. She walks off. Bobby Joe looks stunned. When recovers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Wait up, wait up, come on, baby. You playin’ with me? What’s your name? How come you speak such good English?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: The name’s Tina. I go to the same school you do and I don’t fall for bullshit. My Momma taught me better than that.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: (gazing after her) Mercy Jesus. A black seniorita. ON THE DANCE FLOOR Orsten and Worsley dance with SENIORIT Worsley, taller than the girl, steps on her foot. She loo at his platform boots and giggles. ON STAGE Cager sings w a MARIACHI in a huge sombrero and silver studded outfit, “crying” to the Mariachi violins and trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross walks in fishing gear. The players stumble up, drunk sombreros, singing "La Cucaracha". A sober Shed supports

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Right on, brother. You look like one of them men from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You peckerheads better hit the showers and get that cantina stink off you. You got practice. If coach finds out-~

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: He ain’t gonna find out, Daddy-O. We too cool to give ourselves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players lined up in a row, looking nervous. Haskins p in front of their faces, his eyes boring into each player  34.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Gonna be a long practice today, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You don’t look too good, Bobby Joe.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Huh, what? I'll tell you what. When I set rules, I set rules. And if you break ‘em-- I‘m on you like ugly on a baboon’s butt. (on snickers of the others) Anybody-- bitten by the evil worm last night runs me one hundred lines right now. The rest of you get to watch. Bobby Joe, Orsten, Cager, Worsley, Flournoy jog onto the court. Haskins looks at Shed. He holds up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I never touch the stuff, Coach. LATER: The players drag down court as the others count “n nine, a hundred!”. They collapse. Moe blows his WHISTLE.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Time for drills! Pick and roll!! LATER: Shed eats up Baudoin and scores. He CLAPS his hand grinning, strutting his trademark victory strut.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Cut that out, Shed. You look like a goddamn hyena out there.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Just feelin' the joy, Coach! Feelin' the joy! LATER: Cager charges down court with frantic energy. He m the basket, but stumbles. He gets up quickly, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You made the team, Cager. Don’t need to kill yourself for every basket.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Willie Cager give 110 percent. Every time.  35.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Coach-- I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don't see no sweat, Hill.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe Hill don't sweat. The players laugh, calling "Alright-- 'No Sweat Hill'!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well, seeing you don't sweat, why don’t we work double time tonight? Ross, cancel dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’s boys sit on the steps, dressed in Daniel Boone outf water flasks, toy guns at their sides. They’ve been waiti for hours, crestfallen. Mary comes out and puts down a tr of Oreos and milk and ruffles their hair, consolingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players drill sprint and cover, sweat drenched, exhau

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I never saw a sorrier bunch'a guys. We ain't gonna make it to the opening of the season, much less win any damn games, if you guys don’t shape up. Come on, come on, let’s get your feet burnin’! Haskins blows his WHISTLE. The players slump in a circle.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Because a few players screwed around last night, I missed ‘Gunsmoke’ and the rest of you burned holes in your shoes. Now I don't like missing ‘Gunsmoke’. So follow the rules-- No booze, no women, no Juarez. It happens again, you're off the team-- Now get some sleep. We start early tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins drags himself inside. Throwing his playbook on th couch he sees Mary in the kitchen door. She is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Your boys sat outside for three hours waitin’ on you. Where you been?  36.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Damn. I forgot. I was workin’.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Working... working all the time. Mary walks off. Don stands, miserable. He walks to the bo bedroom. Mark lies in bed with his toy gun, still awake. kneels by him, speaking with tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Hey, partner-- we’re partners, right? And partners don’t let each other down, do they?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Well, I forgot I was takin’ you coyote huntin’ toady. And I let you boys down. I want you to know I’m real sorry for that. But-- we'll get ‘em next time, okay? They’11 be running under rocks and duckin’ in the dust. Right, partner? Mark nods, smiling. Don ruffles his hair and smiles lovin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a geology lab class room full of white students, Flour Shed, and Bobby Joe sit at a table, wearing goggles, sift through ROCKS, trying to identify them. The teacher paces watching all the white students scribbling feverishly as black players turn the rocks in their hands, totally conf The girl from the Juarez bar, Tina, comes up and takes a from Bobby Joe’s hand. She lays it on the matching chart. looks at her and smiles. She smiles back a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flournoy stands before Haskins as he reads his transcript

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You're a smart kid, Harry. But these grades ain’t pullin’ the truck up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I know. But every class is about rocks. I’m a black man. I don’t do rocks.  37.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: But you get the importance of an education. Trying your best on and off the court?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Then you bring your grades up in two weeks, Harry. Or else. You got me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palacio and Flournoy leave together at the end of a class

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: Hey, man, you wanna study together?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna study that shit.

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: Didn’t you get a warning from Coach?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: What’s he gonna do? He’s already run my ass ragged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. FLOURNOY STOMPS DOWN THE HALL, nostrils flaring. Flo and Palacio round the corner. Flournoy’s eyes widen in sh

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Flournoy is in the back of the classroom, in coat an hands folded over her purse. Flournoy in the front, miser

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Who can tell me the field classification of phaneritic rocks?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: (raising her hand; pointed) My son, Harry, can.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: (looking down; chagrined) Yes, Ma’‘am. Granitoid, Syenitoid, Gabbroid...  38. Mrs. Flournoy smiles, smugly satisfied as the students st INT. HALLWAY OF DORMITORY - SHED’S DOOR - NIGHT Shed stands at the door, THE IMPRESSIONS “Gypsy Woman” pl inside. He hesitates, then opens the door. INSIDE... Lattin is under the sheets with an unseen woman Shed comes in, Lattin leaps up, wrapping the sheet around himself, pushing Shed into the hallway and up against the

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: You never ever enter when I’m entertaining a lady friend. You understand me, Gumby?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Hey man, I-- I-- didn’t know. I--

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: (pointing at vent in door) Check the vent, Gumby. That vent’s open, it's too hot for you to come in. You dig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shed sits next to the door, bored. MUSIC still plays. He looks at his watch. Then he looks around. No one is in si Slowly he inches his way toward the vent until he is crouching close enough to peek inside. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lock yourself out, Sonny? Shed screams, turning to see Ross standing there with fis gear. Shed hurries away. Ross watches him go, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are dressing for practice, throwing towels. T stands with Armstrong demonstrating a bizarre cheering technique, hyperventilating, his cheeks bulging, face red

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You’re gonna pass out like that, Togo.

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: (catching his breath) Naw. It's just to get me pumped up to cheer the team on. I never pass out. Baudoin is at a sink, dousing his jersey with water, grin slyly. The others gather around him, watching, suspicious  39.

dialogues.speaker: MYERS
dialogues.text: Hey, Flip? What are you doin’ there?

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: Nothing, man. Not-a-thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baudoin charges down court, shirt drenched with water.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Everybody take a look at Baudoin. He's workin’ hard. He's drippin' some sweat. Let that be an example to the rest of you. The others glare as Baudoin grins. Lattin pounds Shed at basket. Shed bails, tangling his feet. Lattin pushes Shed making him fall, and scores.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Shed??? You're like a duck! You wake up in a new world every day.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: He keeps foulin' me, Coach!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: The hell he’s fouling! You're backing up! What are you gonna do when it's a real game? Back down every time somebody puts a body on you? How many times do I have to tell you? You go sit down. Come back when you're ready to play! All the way! LATER: Cager makes a flying jump-hook. As he releases the ball he teeters, disoriented, looking shaken.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What was that, Cager?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Nothin’, Coach. I slipped.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: No, that was a playground shot. Why don’t you try that again and do it right.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: I got it in, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: It's not just about the hole, Mister Cager, it's about the path you take to get there. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASKINS (cont'd) (to snickers of others) You think that’s funny? This team does not play playground ball. We play fundamental, disciplined, defensive basketball! Togo. Show Mr. Cager how to shoot a basket. Nervous, Togo dribbles and makes a shot. Cager mimics Tog

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: You want me to do that?! What about my stylin’? I got too much style to do that.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You leave the stylin’ for your Mama’s shoes. Show me you belong in the NCAA. Cager takes it to the basket, makes the shot, looking pai

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Good. Let’s all try that now. The black players try to play stiff and disciplined. Bobb finally breaks out and dribbles through his legs for a la

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Hill!?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Had to do it, Coach. All that set shoot honkey ball. My arms are cramping up.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (in his face) You do not make a joke out of my practice!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You think you know it all? You think you got nothing to learn from me, Hill? I got nothing to teach you, Hill?!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: No, Coach, I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Then how you gonna beat Division One talent playing like you're on a playground?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: It’s not just up to me, Coach.  41.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: No, it isn't! That's cause you got a team playin’ with you! I wanna see you play with that team, if you plan on winning any games. So any one of you playgrounders globetrots your flashy, no account basketball behinds around, you’1ll find yourselves on the bench! Tomorrow I wanna see real basketball! Now get outta here. The players drag themselves from the gym. Ross walks up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You wanna take it a little easy, Sonny? You're gettin’ the guys kinda down.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Ross, those boys are playing like they’re on two different teams. They don’t know what it’s like out there. They need to play the enemy’s game. And that takes discipline and control. We've got two weeks left before the season starts and they don’t know anything yet. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Ray stands with WADE RICHARDSON and other BOOSTERS. T look inside at the players through a window in the door.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: There’s seven of them.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: Actually twelve in all, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: Yes, but seven of those other ones.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: Coach thinks he’s got a real strong team this year.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: Where'd you find this coach?

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: He’s from Oklahoma, sir. Richardson just nods, staying silent.  42. INT. ARMSTRONG’S ROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT ROGER MILLER plays on a radio. The white players sit, moo INT.

dialogues.speaker: MYERS
dialogues.text: Coach is more interested in the black players than us. Don’t we play just as hard?

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: We might as well not even be out there.

dialogues.speaker: MEN'S LOUNGE
dialogues.text: The black players look dejected. A TV shows a pre~season college basketball: IMAGES of WHITE TEAMS like IOWA, KANS KENTUCKY, smiling wide, a bright shining world of basketb

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Coach ain’t human. I think he rides our black asses harder than anyone.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: It ain’t fair. Pickin’ on us like that.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Far as I’m concerned, he’s like all the rest. The back of his neck is a shade too red. Worsley takes off his shoes. His feet are bleeding. He wi

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Playground basketball. If he don’t want us to play our game why'd he bring us here at all? They look at the grinning WHITE FACES of the BIG WHITE SC

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Look at that. Smilin’ like that.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: We ain’‘t never gonna be like that.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Nah... They fall silent. Shed finally stretches.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I‘m beat. I’m going to bed.  43.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Least tomorrow’s Sunday. I’m gonna sleep ‘till noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash light weaves through the hall. Ross walks into fr a mining helmet on his head. He is dressed half fly- fisherman, half astronaut. He throws open a door. Yells.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Rise and shine, boys! I got good news! He bangs on another door. Faces appear, sleepy, disorient

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: What the hell, Ross?--

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You boys been workin’ so hard, I figure a little change’a scenery’1l do ya good! We're gonna have some fun, El Paso style. Lattin glowers at him. Ross slams a FISHING NET into his

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You too, Big Daddy. No arguments. We're goin’ frog giggin’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HEAR ROY ORBISON “Blue Bayou”. FROGS CROAK IN A SHALLO BED. Ross, Flournoy, Worsley, Cager, Togo, Shed, Armstron Lattin sit in row boats, wearing mining helmets. Ross plu his hand into the water and tosses a frog in the sack. Th bounces inside. Ross holds it up in triumph. They stare b

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Ross. This brother don't hunt no frogs. I'm from the Bronx, man!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Hey, this is better than huntin’ back country coon! Come on guys, try it. The black players sit, unmoving. Suddenly Lattin plunges big bare hands into the murky water. He comes up with a f

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Got one!

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Hey, we in the Wild Kingdom now!

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Big Daddy D’s a regular Marlin Perkins! Lattin grins and tosses a frog at Shed. Shed HOWLS and fl it away. The scene dissolves in laughing, splashing, and frogs flying into the sack. Shed suddenly looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Ross?! What are we gonna do with them once we got ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross flicks on all the showers, water RAINING DOWN. Armst is dumping the bags into the showers. Frogs are everywher

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s a french delicacy type deal. You cut ‘em up and fry ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Black people don't eat that stuff, Ross. I'm tellin' you, we don't eat no frogs. Armstrong and Togo scamper after frogs. Ross brings up a knife to slice the legs of a frog. Shed doubles over, HEA

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: The French are fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worsley and Lattin sit on the steps, eating frog legs.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: This ain't bad. Not bad at all. Lattin grunts and nods, chewing.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: You know, Big Daddy, I always hated angry big guys like you. But you alright.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: That’s nice of you to say, Willie. Coming from an angry short man like you.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Big Daddy, what made you come here?

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: I wanna be the best. Best at my game.  45.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: I come to go to school. I mean, I‘'1l jump and run and play this game, but I ain’t playin’ fool forever. That's where they wanna keep you, you know. Playin’ games. Not Willie Worsley. I got a plan. I’m gonna graduate. I’m gonna get ahead. Basketball’s just a way to get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shed stands across as Haskins holds out a sealed envelope

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Here's a ticket. I’m sending you home.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Home?! The season’s ten days away! You can’t send me home!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Yes, I can. One minute you're running around like a clown; like some crazy wild man; then you back down, afraid to go up for rebounds. That’s when I send you home.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Coach. Mama's gonna beat my ass!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I can't have a big man who's afraid to play like one. That's just the way it is. Haskins looks back down at his papers. Shed turns away, c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe stands in the darkness, dressed to the nines. C and Flournoy pass him by.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: You lookin’ sharp, Bobby Joe. You in for some trouble tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Brothers, I am on the trail of love.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: What about the rules, man?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Only one rule tonight. Bobby Joe Hill’s gonna get him some bone cat.  46. The others SLAP his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Stand back. Bobby Joe’s got work. The others grin as he walks away. Just then Haskins passe by. His eyes narrowed he sees Bobby Joe walking away.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What’s he doin’? They shrug. Haskins looks back at Bobby Joe, wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candle light and OTIS REDDING'S "Try a Little Tenderness” Bobby Joe pours Tina some Mogen David wine. She smirks.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: You know all the moves, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't no move, baby. I'm comin' from the heart.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: But how many hearts do you have?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I like to have a good time. The Magic Man tries not to take anything too seriously. Bobby leans in and tries to kiss her. Tina pushes him awa

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: This isn't a game for me, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I know, baby.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything. Tina kisses Bobby Joe long and hard. His eyes widen as sh pushes him back, smiling. SUDDENLY the door BUSTS OPEN. H comes in. Bobby Joe jumps. Haskins sees the bottles of wi Tina on the bed.- He looks at Bobby Joe with frightening

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins drills Bobby Joe up and down the stairs. Sweat drenched, he’s been at it a long, hard time, breathless.  47.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Please, Coach, I can't go no more!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I think you can go some more. You got energy for all kinda nonsense. Instead of puttin’ it in your team. Instead of respecting yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I got no team. We ain’t goin’ nowhere. You tellin’ us all the time how bad we are. We know we ain’t never gonna win. What have I got to respect?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You don’t get it, Bobby Joe. The guys look up to you. Any one of them would give anything to have your talent. You're my best player. But what do you do? You act the fool, make it all a joke... when you could be the leader of this team. Bobby Joe looks struck. He reaches the bottom and looks a Haskins. Then he bends over and vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don sits at the table, reading the paper. PHOTOS show POL OFFICERS BEATING BLACKS under the headline: "RIOTS BREAK IN WATTS". Mary sets down steak and eggs and sits across.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: It’s gettin’ crazy out there.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Honey, I was thinking. Don’t you think you're being a little hard on those guys?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You too, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, you work so hard all the time, sometimes I think you lose sight of what really matters. It’s not like there's some pot at the end of the rainbow. What’s it all gonna bring, all the pain you’re puttin’ those kids through?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: They need to be strong. They have no idea what's out there. Now maybe it’s painful. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASKINS (cont'd) Maybe they hate me for pushing them so hard. But you have to understand, nobody out there thinks black kids can play NCAA basketball-- everybody wants them to fail.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: They’re just kids, Don. What good is winning if you break their spirit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shed is packing his suitcase, alone, full of turmoil. He turns the shirt in his hand, staring. Then he throws it d and turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are gathered before Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: In a few days we open the season. Some of you may think that I've been too hard on you these last three months. And maybe I overdid it sometimes. But if I pushed you, it was to see if you could keep going. If I made you hate me, it was to see you play through that hate. If I was the enemy, it was only to see you bond together as a team. Because the enemy-- is out there. The players listen, silent.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You spent three months learning to play the enemy’s game on the enemy’s terms. You see, out there they think a team like you can’t win. They think players like Bobby Joe ain’t mentally tough enough. That Worsley or Flournoy will fold under pressure. Or Lattin’ll run outta control “cause he can’t think. Or that Cager doesn’t have the heart to win. (beat) So nobody expects us to do a thing this year. We’re just Texas Western to them. But I expect big things because I know-- if you just play as the team that I know you can be-- you will beat the enemy’s game. Just remember to play-- (the players chime in, smiling) fundamental, disciplined, defensive basketball!... Let's go out there and play Texas Western basketball and for the first time-- make those words mean something!!  49. The guys CHEER. Haskins turns and sees Shed walk up to hi

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Coach. I can do this. Give me one more chance. I want to be a part of this team. HASKINS. No more ducking? No more Shed in dreamland?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: No, Coach. No more.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You got one more chance.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Guess I don’t need this anymore. Shed holds up the envelope. Haskins takes it, pulls out a blank piece of paper and shreds it up.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: You mean-- it was never a real ticket?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You prove me right, Shed. SHED . I will, Coach. I will!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. SERIES OF IMAGES
dialogues.text: MEMORIAL GYM... Armstrong holds the ladder as Ross fixes ceiling lights. Mary comes in with a BANNER FOR THE MINER Armstrong helps her and lets go. CLOSE ON ROSS. He looks teetering. Suddenly he DISAPPEARS FROM FRAME. IN THE HALLWAY OUTSIDE LATTIN and Shed’s room... Shed and several other black players are crouched at the vent of t door, crowding each other out, trying to get a peek insid MEMORIAL GYM... The players pose for a team photo. Everyo grimaces a tense smile as the FLASH whites out screen. INT. BOBBY JOE’S ROOM - NIGHT Bobby Joe and Orsten lie in their beds in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: I hear you breathin’.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I breathe, man.  50.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: You nervous about the game?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I ain’t nervous. I ain’t never nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: What'd Coach say to you after the dance anyway? How come you’re still on the team?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: He said I should be a leader and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: That‘s funny.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What‘s funny about that?

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: You know. You a leader.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: That ain’t funny. Why’s that funny?

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Don’t worry about it. (a silence) What you think’s gonna happen tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: You nervous? Bobby Joe throws his pillow and hits Orsten in the head.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. EASTERN NEW MEXICO FANS dot the gym. A BRASS BAND plays. CHEERLEADERS dance school FIGHT SONG. Opposing EASTERN NEW MEXICO warms up a MILTON, a short, chain-smoking ANNOUNCER speaks into a mi

dialogues.speaker: JUD MILTON
dialogues.text: This is Jud Milton, ‘Voice of the Miners' comin' to you from Memorial Gym where Texas Western will open the season against the Greyhounds from Eastern New Mexico. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD MILTON (cont'd) We'll be back for the tip off after this word from the sponsor of Miners Basketball, Wade Richardson West Texas Furniture Emporium! WE HEAR a JINGLE. A WOMEN’S CHORUS sings “Who's the bigge in the furniture business? Wade Rich-ard-son".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are dressing. Shed keeps looking into the gym

dialogues.speaker: SHED
