dialogues.text: What time is it, Scoop? Is it time?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Coach'1l let us know. Take it easy. Flournoy is obsessively tying his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: You tied that shoe five times. They put people away for stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Just makin’ sure it’s right. Togo goes to Bobby Joe who sits dozing, toothpick in his

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: Look at him. He’s sleeping! Nobody can be that relaxed. The others gather round him, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: That guy has nerves of steel. Moe sticks his head in and blows his WHISTLE. Bobby Joe w startled. He sees the faces around him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What you lookin’ at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Eastern New Mexico players stand on the court, all wh

dialogues.speaker: JUD MILTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a night of questions. Will Don Haskins, the little known Oklahoma coach of the Benjamin championship girls team, be able to lift the Miners to respectability? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUD MILTON (V.0.) (cont'd) Will the "new look" Miners, and I do mean new look, be able to compete on a national level against the country’s top recruits? The Miners enter to a small CHEER from the crowd. The sta are half empty. Haskins sees Mary and the boys. They wave REFEREE BLOWS a WHISTLE.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM ANOUNCER
dialogues.text: And now your ‘Texas Western Miners’! At guard, El Paso's own, David Palacio!-- (cheers for the hometown boy) Forward, Jerry Armstrong. (more cheers) From Detroit, Michigan, guard, Bobby Joe Hill! (a surprised silence falls) From Indiana, Forward, Harry Flournoy... At center, David ‘Big Daddy D’ Lattin! IN THE CROWD... people are looking at the black faces, murmuring, confused and wary. IN THE STANDS... WADE RICHARDSON sits with another BOOSTE

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: We look like the damn Tuskeegee Institute out there. All those Negros he’s playin’. Just when did we become a black school?

dialogues.speaker: BOOSTER
dialogues.text: Guess that ol’ boy got used to doin’ things his way down in Oklahoma.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: This isn’t Oklahoma and he doesn’t write the checks at Texas Western. Wade Richardson does. And it’s about time he found that out. ON THE FLOOR... The Announcer speaks into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM ANOUNCER
dialogues.text: El Paso! Let's hear it for your 1965 Texas Western Miners! Slowly, the crowd breaks into cautious APPLAUSE. FIRST HALF: Lattin stands in against the opposing CENTER. off goes to the Miners. The Miners break out, but play st Bobby Joe gets the ball to Orsten but Orsten MISSES.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What was that, Orsten?! Come on!  53. Cager spins off a hook shot but Eastern New Mexico interc Haskins leaps off the bench.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What do you think you're playing, a zone?! Stick to your man! Worsley! You're in for Palacio. Texas Western is behind 18-22. Fans look on, skeptical. ON COURT... Determined, Bobby Joe dishes a perfect pass t Cager for two. They high five. Armstrong holds a hulking FORWARD back. Worsley slips under and SCORES. 32-34 TEXAS WESTERN. Togo leaps up, cheering them on, hyperventilatin

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: Togo. Stop actin’ like a white man. Bobby Joe dribbles through his legs in a dazzling move. IN THE CROWD... A kid’s mouth drops at Bobby Joe’s playin HASKINS © Stop showboating, Hill! SERIES OF IMAGES: Miners battle for every shot. The score stays close. Haskins paces the sideline, yelling, exhorti

dialogues.speaker: JUD MILTON
dialogues.text: Texas Western’s sure playing competitive basketball tonight. With Coach Haskins going against all convention, starting three blacks and two whites-- if nothing else they are bound to stand out on the floor this season. FINAL BUZZER. TEXAS WESTERN 62-- EASTERN NEW MEXICO 58. Silence, then a huge CHEER FROM EL PASO FANS. Don slaps h players as they run off court. The Forward sneers at Shed

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD
dialogues.text: You got lucky tonight, Buckwheat. It's a long season.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY
dialogues.text: “Shotgun” by JR. WALKER & THE ALL STARS. The players celebrate, high-fiving, singing to the radio. Bobby Joe g Armstrong's hand in a brother shake, singing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE/ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: I said shotgun-- shoot him 'fore he run now...  54.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: That was a close one, Sweepee. But we had it goin’ on. You see that twenty five footer I put in? All net, baby.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: He called me Buckwheat.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Let him call you Buckwheat. Cream of Wheat. Scoreboard is all that counts in the end.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Maybe. I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins sits in front with Ross. The radio plays JOHNNY RIVERS “Poor Side Of Town”. Ross sings along loudly.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Poor side’a town, right. Johnny Rivers white ass wouldn't know the poor side of town if you dropped him off in the middle of it. Baudoin turns up his radio looking at Flournoy. We hear B DYLAN “Times They Are A Changing”.

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: You hear the new Dylan? He’s got a social conscience, man.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Too bad he can’t sing. Armstrong brings his radio up front blaring “The Ballad O The Green Berets” by SGT. BARRY SADLER.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Check this out! You guys know this song? This dude is real talented.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: A singing sergeant? Only white folks could dig that. He turns up his radio: FOUR TOPS “Reach Out I‘ll Be There

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Now we got a groove on.  55. As he lip synchs, Lattin slowly adjusts the volume on his rigged radio with giant speakers in the back.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: You cats gotta get with it, man. He cranks ROLLING STONES “Satisfaction”, drowning out the rest. Haskins looks pained as the song blasts through the He exchanges a look with Ross who shrugs and shakes his h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ATTENDANT fills up the bus. As black players buy “Coke at a vending machine, HOT RODS pull up with a DRUNKEN GAN THUGS. The LEADER looks at the black guys.

dialogues.speaker: LEADER
dialogues.text: Well, what do we have here? On cue the thugs circle the bus and shake it on its wheel

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Cut that out! The black players come running, but Haskins waves them on bus. The bus rumbles to life. Moe quickly turns and is th last on the bus as it drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players watch the thugs recede in the distance, distu Flournoy sits by Armstrong. He looks at him, sarcastic.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Friends of yours, Farm Boy?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: (sneering back) How do you play with that giant chip on your shoulder? Flournoy frowns and moves to another part of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miners’ bus rolls into Commerce, Texas, home of “East Texas State University”. There are cattle trucks. Men in Stetsons lingering on street corners.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. EAST TEXAS STATE  56. The EAST TEXAS ANNOUNCERS watch, stunned, as the Miners f three black players amongst the whites in their line up.

dialogues.speaker: EAST TEXAS ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: This ole boy Haskins sure is raisin’ some eyebrows playin’ those coloreds. What's he got-- three out there?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Jest shows you how desperate this program is to get a few wins this season. FIRST HALF: Miners battle East Texas. But East Texas musc in shots the Miners can’t stop. Miners behind 12~28. Bobb loses the ball. Haskins paces the sideline, aggravated.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe! Dammit! Defense! What was that?! An East Texas player trash talks Orsten. Orsten hesitates East Texas picks him and scores. Haskins throws up his ha

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Keep your head in the game! THE BUZZER. Haskins looks at the HALFTIME SCORE: TEXAS WESTERN 30, EAST TEXAS 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands with Bobby Joe, alone.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What are you doing out there?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Coach. We can’t play like this.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Just stick to the plan, Bobby Joe.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You want me to be a leader? How can I lead if you don’t let me? We're handcuffed out there. You need to let us loose a little bit. We know all about their game, but we got some game of our own. (beat) You made a lot of promises, Coach. But you just the same as the rest. Bobby Joe walks off. Haskins watches him, frustrated.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND HALF: Miners continue to struggle. SCORE is 38-57 TEXAS. Haskins sits, arms folded, thinking. Staring at th score. Watching his players. Watching the clock. East Tex scores. Haskins calls a time out and signals Bobby Joe ov

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You saying you can get this done?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Just give us a little room, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Alright. I’1l roll the dice on you, Bobby Joe. But just a little room. Bobby Joe grins and nods and runs back onto the court. SERIES OF IMAGES: The Miners battle back, looking like a TEAM, Bobby Joe spurs each player on, as Miners come back Lattin muscles in shots above the rim. Bobby Joe steals b for lay-ups. Cager makes flying jump hooks. Ross paces th sideline, tossing his towel. Haskins watches everything. comes on a BIG MAN. For a moment he could back down, but doesn’t, and makes the bank shot. Even Haskins leaps up.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Shed! You wild man! That’s the way! An East Texas GUARD is all over Bobby Joe. The Guard snee nasty. But Bobby Joe goes into a dribble drive and SCORES passes the Guard, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You dropped somethin’, brother.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: A step. As the Miners pull ahead, the crowd becomes more and more hostile. Flournoy skies for a rebound and the fans “BOO”.

dialogues.speaker: EAST TEXAS ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: What is it we're watching here, Hank?  58.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Can't say, Bob. I don't know what's gotten into the Miners, but East Texas better pull somethin’ out of the hat or Commerce is outta business tonight. Bobby Joe SCORES lay up after lay up as the FINAL BUZZER SOUNDS. SCOREBOARD reads: TEXAS WESTERN 74 -- EAST TEXAS Haskins leaps off the bench, together with Togo, excited. INT. MINER’S BUS - MOVING - LATER THAT NIGHT MIners celebrate, high fiving, singing to JAMES BROWN, “Papa’s Got A Brand New Bag” on the radio. Haskins watche them. Moe looks at him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Looks like we got us a team, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We just might, Squeaky, we just might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus parks as the team files in to hostile stares from people in the lobby. The players note it as Haskins check INT. HALLWAY TO MOTEL ROOM — LATER Haskins passes a stranger as he fumbles for his key. He r the door and goes to unlock it but the door opens by itse INSIDE THE ROOM... Haskins enters, on edge. He flips on t light. He looks around when something catches his eye. CLOSE UP: A NOTE on the table. He picks it up: “You hang with niggers. People like you get what’s coming.” STAY on Haskins look of concern. INT. CAGER AND SHED’S ROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT Cager and Shed lounge on the beds when Worsley sneaks ins

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Brothers, you ain’t gonna believe this! There's a party on the edge of town. Bobby Joe met some chicks. Chocolate ladies. Enough to go around. Who in? Cager and Shed grin at each other and leap up.  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small house under a starry sky. SMOKEY ROBINSON “Ooh, B Baby”. Cars parked outside. Figures making out in back se

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A house party underway. The lights are low. A table cover biscuits and ribs. Shed helping himself, licking his fing

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Mmmm-mmmm. Almost as good as Mama’s. People dancing, drinking. Sofas and chairs covered with people making out. Worsley dances slowly with a beautiful tall black girl, his head on her chest. Lattin kisses a g in a corner. Cager tugs a giggling girl toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TEMPTATIONS “Papa Was A Rolling Stone”. Cager and the pass Worsley, Flournoy and Orsten talking, arigging beers

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: I’m tellin’ you, it’s gonna get bad out there. The white racist establishment ain’t just roll over and make room for us niggers.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Why. We’re just playin’ a game.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Don’t matter. We’re breakin’ their rules, brother, and they'll come after us for it. But doesn’t mean we have take it. I mean, in New York we don’t no shit from white folk.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we ain’t in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud crowd packs the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. ABILENE AN USHER leads a BLACK FAMILY to their seats. They follow usher to the top of the arena, far away from any other pe seated. The father takes out his tickets.  60.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK FATHER
dialogues.text: These aren't our seats.

dialogues.speaker: USHER
dialogues.text: They are now. THE HUGE WHITE CROWD CHANTS "Abilene!", "Abilene!", "Abil ON THE FLOOR... Haskins watches all white, athletic Abile warm up with precise and rigorous drills. Their COACH com

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE COACH
dialogues.text: You got some balls takin' on those boys. I could see playin’ one, but two or three-- that’s like lettin’. the animals outta the zoo.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don’t recall asking your advice.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE COACH
dialogues.text: I hope you know the risk you’re runnin’. We have rules in this game. Unwritten rules. You break ‘em, you might find yourself out of the coaching business for good. The coach walks off. Haskins gathers his players, mad.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Last game we played great, but Abilene is bigger and stronger. Just stay focused, stay clear, boys. Keep your head in the game and we can win this baby! On three!

dialogues.speaker: MINERS
dialogues.text: The players CHEER and take the floor for the tip off.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Center. Lattin. Guard. Hill. Forward. Armstrong. Forward. Baudoin. Guard. Worsley. GAME: The BUZZER. Tip off. Miners get a fast start. Freed now, they play loose and confident, going deep and playin above the rim. Bobby Joe sets up scores, feeding Lattin, Shed, Orsten. Abilene just can’t keep up. IN THE STANDS... Disgruntled ABELINE FANS sneer.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ABELINE FAN
dialogues.text: That ain't basketball. All that fancy jumpin’ like monkeys.  61.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ABELIENE
dialogues.text: Let ‘em try that against the big boys. They’11 be shootin’ circles ‘round them coons. HALF TIME BUZZER: 51 to 46 Miners. SECOND HALF: Miners keep scoring, pulling out of reach fo Abilene. A sneering Abilene FORWARD, a red-head, clutches ball tight, and taunts Cager with the others in earshot.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD
dialogues.text: Your coach need a special license to bring you spades here? Angry, Cager goes up for a flying jump-hook, but he loses bearings suddenly and falls back, losing the ball, shaken The Forward quickly makes a move for the ball, but Shed fights it away from him and scores. He does his victory s as the others high five him. END BUZZER. FINAL SCORE: Miners 84 to 67. Abilene fans JE and BOO. Haskins runs from the court, into the LOCKER ROO TUNNEL with Moe, Ross and the players. Fans throw program half-empty cups of beer as the players duck the onslaught Inside the tunnel Cager and Bobby Joe stop, watching the of trash, with grim expressions. -

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Look at ‘em, man. They hate us. The more we win. The more they hate us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miners come outside, talking, laughing with Haskins a Ross. SEVERAL DRUNKEN ABILENE FANS appear in the darkness walking past. They see the Miners and jeer.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN FAN
dialogues.text: Hey Shoeshines, you're in the wrong part of the country!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DRUNKEN FAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, goddamn porchmonkeys! Why don't you coons play real basketball next time? Flournoy lunges at them and Worsley right beside him.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: I can take ‘em, Coach!  62.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Nobody calls me a coon! I swear, I'll take them out--- Haskins holds Flournoy. The other black players press up.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Nobody moves! Nobody! Flournoy stands, chest heaving. Lattin behind him, with B Joe, Orsten. They watch the hecklers walk off.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We got more important things to think about. We have basketball games to win. Let's win the battles that count. The black players look back at Haskins, with dark looks.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You keep playin’ the way you play, you can keep winnin’ games. Don’t be thinkin’ about them. They don’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Coach is right. We’re okay. Right? The others reluctantly nod.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Come on, team. Let’s us go win some games! We gonna get us some r-e-s-p-e-— ce-t! Find out what it means to me-- The others join in singing ARETHA FRANKLIN'S "Respect.

dialogues.speaker: PLAYERS
dialogues.text: R-E-S-P-E-C-T. Take care, TCB. (SHED BELLOWING: Sock It To Me, Sock It To Me, Sock It To Me, etc.) a little respect...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ON THE ROAD
dialogues.text: LITTLE EVA'S “The Locomotion”. INTERCUT the Miners taking various teams. They SUFFOCATE ON DEFENSE, RUN THE BREAK w dazzling SPEED, CRASH THE BOARDS, winning game after game the same time INTERCUT IMAGES OF HECKLERS in the crowds, SKEPTICAL ANNOUNCERS sneering into their microphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a huge Elk looming over his large office desk, Wade Richardson sits, addressing Dr. Ray.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: For twelve years, I have been a good friend to the university. I support basketball, football, put up the money for the stadium-- always had Texas Western in my heart.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: We couldn't have done any of it without you, Mr. Richardson. Richardson rises and looks out at his furniture warehouse

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: But I got a little problem with this Coach Haskins and all the colored boys he’s playin’. He’s got three, four of them out there every game. Why’s he do that? He doesn’t need them to win, does he?

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: Mr. Richardson. We’re undefeated.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: It's not just about winning. The Miners reflect on my business. When we were just a losing team, we loved ‘em anyway. They were our boys. Now we got all these Negroes from who knows where. Those ain’t our boys. Now that may be fine for El Paso. But I got stores in Lubbock and Amarillo, and our new look doesn't play real well over there. And that hurts my business. And what hurts my business, hurts the Miners, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: I can’t tell Coach Haskins how to coach his team.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: His team? That team doesn’t have jock straps if I don’t pay for them. You tell him to bench those black players or I withdraw my support. And that’s the end of Texas Western Athletics. Understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MIDWEST. Green hills, hay bales. Barns and weather va "God Bless America” signs with flags and smiling white pe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don sits with IOWA COACH, RALPH MILLER, fielding question

dialogues.speaker: FIRST REPORTER
dialogues.text: The A.P. has you at number six, Coach Miller. You're undefeated. Do you anticipate any problems against Texas Western tonight?

dialogues.speaker: COACH MILLER
dialogues.text: Well, they come at you with a little different look, if you know what I mean. (as the reporters laugh knowingly) But if we play Iowa basketball, we should be able to pick this one off easy. I'm more concerned about Kansas. Kentucky. You know. The big schools.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: Coach Haskins, as a small school, how do you plan to take on a program with the pedigree of Iowa?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We're just lucky to be playin’ a team with such a great tradition.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST REPORTER
dialogues.text: Coach Haskins, you're playing a lot of colored kids and you've had some success. Do you really think Negro players are capable winning at this level?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I guess that’s why they keep score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are dressing. Flournoy stands looking at the white fans streaming into the arena. Baudoin stops Haskin

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: Coach, you gonna give me some court time this game?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We'll, see, Flip. We’ll see.  65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miners and Hawkeyes warm-up in the packed arena.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. IOWA IN THE CROWD... SEVERAL BLACK FANS take their places, ign dirty looks, trying to catch a glimpse of the Miners, exc

dialogues.speaker: FIRST IOWA ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Texas Western sure has gotten a lot of attention this season, playin’ his high risk Negro ball, but let’s all remember they have yet to play a top program. Until tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Well, Bob, Coach Miller has wanted to test his bench. It’s safe to say he‘1ll get his opportunity tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL HERMAN CARR washing dishes. A TV plays in his view SCREEN: Texas Western lines up for the tip off. A fellow employee flips it to “Green Acres”.

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Stop! Leave the game on! I know that guy! INT. HAWKEYE ARENA —- SAME TIME Miners win the tip as the HAWKEYE CROWD shakes the rafter Miners swarm all over, stealing balls, causing turnovers. The press corps stare in shock as Coach Miller jumps, screaming, waving his arms in vain. Shed leads the way, scoring at will. Haskins catches him as he passes by and him a big clap on the back. Shed grins, wide as the IOWA ANNOUNCERS sit at their microphones.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST IOWA ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: The Miners sure are playing a kind of basketball like we've never seen in Iowa. Ten minutes into the first quarter and the Hawkeyes have yet to score a field goal! I don’t know what’s going on here but this Texas Western team has silenced the crowd at Hawkeye Arena and is taking apart the number six team in the nation!!  66.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Iowa just seems unable to counter Texas Western's unique brand of ball. Their defense has shut down the Hawkeyes. They’re getting three shots off to every one set shot. Shooting deep and taking the ball above the rim. Looks like Coach Haskins has abandoned basketball for street tactics just to gain the upper hand tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carr has forgotten his work and CHEERS each shot. Excited accidentally knocks over a stack of plates, shattering to thousand pieces. Fellow workers look at him like he’s cra

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: You got ‘em! Go inside! Sweet. Sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsten scores with his trademark sky “J's”. Armstrong mus up to the Midwestern boys, not letting anybody through. C and Lattin crash the boards and thunder home points.

dialogues.speaker: IOWA ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Time is running out with the score a decisive 86-68, and Texas Western is about to make off with the biggest upset in the nation! Holy Toledo! The FINAL BUZZER SOUNDS. The Miners leap in each others a Towa fans are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND IOWA ANNOUCER
dialogues.text: One can only wonder where this will end up! Haskins and his team have put the great tradition of American basketball on notice tonight! ON HASKINS. REPORTERS crowd him. Photographer's BULBS FLA

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Coach Haskins. I’m with Sports Illustrated. We‘d like to write an article about your team. COACH MILLER, with his coaches, are watching Haskins bein mobbed. His eyes narrowed, his arms crossed, his look gri  67.

dialogues.speaker: COACH MILLER
dialogues.text: He's gonna get his. He’s not gettin’ away with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins and team file in. Open stares come from other tab They try not to notice and sit. Shed hands Cager his menu

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Order me some huevos rancheros.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Dude, this is IHOP! It’s pancakes. They got no huevos rancheros here!

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Damn. I was cravin’ some chile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shed pushes the door open and goes inside when he is sudd grabbed from behind by TWO COLLEGIATE FOOTBALL TYPES. The pull him into a stall and push his face into the toilet b He sputters and fights, but he is held down again into wa

dialogues.speaker: ATTACKER
dialogues.text: Take your nigger ball back home where you belong before we decorate a tree with your black asses! They throw him to the ground, sprawling, gasping for air, blinking, coughing water, and walk out quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are placing their orders to a WAITRESS, as Sh comes up. His clothes are wet. He is shaking, shell shock The waitress stares. It takes a moment longer for the pla to register. Cager and Bobby Joe quickly rise to go to Sh Ross is there a split second later. Everyone looks shocke

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What happened?! What happened to you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lattin is the first outside. He stands, his face in fury, scanning the parking lot and the street for any sign of t attackers. Armstrong comes up, upset. Lattin points.  68.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Coach-- look. In a palm tree, a huge STUFFED ANIMAL MONKEY hangs, a NOO around his neck, a TEXAS WESTERN JERSEY pulled on him.

dialogues.speaker: PALACIO
dialogues.text: (walking up) Holy Mother of Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (with a dark expression) Get in the bus. Go on. Right now! The players look spooked. Slowly they turn away. Cager’s is around Shed. Haskins stands, looking around. Face tigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARVIN GAYE “Heard It Through the Grapevine”. The players silent. There are subdued glances from the white to the b players. Worsley sits with Lattin. He looks at him, quiet

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Big Daddy. You ever get scared?

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: When I was a kid in Houston, white gang strung me up on a fire escape ‘til I peed my pants. I came back down and never took shit from nobody again. Fought everybody honky on the block ‘til they left Big Daddy D alone. But-- this is different. This is worse. It ain't just the neighborhood. This is the whole world. EXT. MINER‘S HALL - EL PASO - LATE AFTERNOON The Miners bus pulls up. A CROWD OF STUDENTS hold up sign “MINERS NUMBER ONE IN OUR HEARTS” and “WELCOME HOME MINER as the players get off. Mary stands with the boys who run embrace Haskins as he appears. Don puts his arms around t Several students stop Bobby Joe as he gets off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: Texas Western! All the way! Bobby Joe nods with a faint smile and goes inside. None o the players stop to talk to the fans. AT THE STEPS to the ADMINISTRATION building Dr. Ray stand watching the Miners go inside with a serious look.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins is eating soup as Mary comes inside with his jack

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Baby. What is it? I’m tired. She sit down and brings out a hate letter, reading, upset

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: ‘Nigger lover. Play those coons and you’re a dead man.’ Don. What are you gonna do?! HASKINS . Nothing. I get those all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You get them all the time?! You have to do something! You have to notify the school! Call the police! HASKINS. And let my players see fear? I can’t do that. We can’t win afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Win? Why is it always about winning?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: If I give in to that-- what would I be teaching them?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This is not some interesting coaching lesson, Don. This is about people’s lives. Your life. Your children. Me. You can't gamble with people's lives.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. I promised those boys. We’re on our way to winning the conference. If we do, we make it to the tournament. We can’t stop now.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: But you've got a family, Don! Do you ever think about your family?!  70.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I‘m thinking of everybody, Mary. I got a big family now. (reaching for her hand) Come on, Mary. I'm trying, honey. I'm trying to make you happy.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I learned a long time ago not to count on my husband for happiness. Mary turns and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe sits with Tina at a make-out spot overlooking E Paso. A lit CROSS rises atop the Juarez mountains.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: You’re quiet tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: What? Sorry. Just thinkin’ I guess. I was thinking how I forgot what it’s really like in the real world. Things are good in El Paso. But when you go out there-- it’s somethin’ else. I never thought about what would happen if we actually won. People really hate us for that, you know? Hate us even more.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: It must be hard for you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I never let things bother me before. I always knew I could walk away. That how I protected myself. I just said I don’t care. (beat) But I do care. And that scares me now. If I care about something, if I want something, that means I could lose it. He looks at her. Her face is luminous in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I’m talkin’ too much. All this serious stuff is messin' up our moonlight drive. Bobby Joe turns up the radio and slides close to her. PER SLEDGE'S "When a Man Loves a Woman" washes over them.  71.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I never said this to anyone before, baby, but when I’m with you-- I feel just right. Tina puts her hand on his mouth and pulls him into a kiss

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe I gotta tell you something’.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Not now, when you lookin’ so fine...

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe-- I’m gonna have a baby. Bobby Joe pulls back, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: A baby? What? I-- can’t do that right now. Not now. Don’t you understand? Tina looks away, deeply struck, fighting tears. Bitter.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: Sure. I understand. He stares ahead. A long silence. He looks at her, awkward

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You have to understand. I have things I gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: TINA
dialogues.text: Don‘t talk anymore, Bobby Joe. Just take me home. He hesitates. Then he starts the car. They drive off. INT. HASKINS’ OFFICE - NEXT DAY Haskins is sitting with Moe and Ross going over the seaso schedule when there is a KNOCK. Dr. Ray looks in.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: Can we talk, Don-- one on one? Moe and Ross look up. Haskins nods to them. They get up a leave. Dr. Ray waits until the door has closed.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What's going on?  72.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: I don't know how to say this. Some of the boosters are a little concerned. They think you're playing-- too many Negros in the games.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: How many Negros do the boosters want me to play? One? Two? What if we lose a game? Then three’s okay?

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: I don't know. You’re playing more and more of them all the time.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’m playing my best players.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: You're going against convention. And people are noticing, and they don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You mean Wade Richardson doesn’t like it. What does he want from me?

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: He wants you to bench the blacks or he’s pullin’ out of the program. And that means there’s no more program.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We are on our way to winning the conference! I can’t change my line up. I’d be risking the season.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: Look. Nobody ever expected you to win like this. It’s already more than we hoped for. It’s gotta end somewhere. Think of the long run. Is it worth the future of the program?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I promised these kids I’d give them a chance. I have to play them.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: But you know as well as I do, what you're doing just isn't done.  73.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I also know we have three more games and we’re in the tournament. I’m not taking away what I promised. We set out to win, and that’s what we’re gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: DR. RAY
dialogues.text: (holding his look) Alright, Don. You do it your way. But I can’t guarantee anything after this point, not even that you’ll have a job when it’s all over.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That’s a gamble I’m gonna have to take. INT. FLOURNOY AND WORSLEY’S ROOM - DAY Worsley paces, reading from a book of Malcolm X speeches.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Why do you keep reading that stuff? They don’t care about fancy words out there.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Words give you power. That’s why you need to learn and graduate. Education gives you power. Only thing a black man can do is get for himself and get ahead. You want change, you got to change yourself.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: All your books. All your education. It’s not gonna help. Nothing’s gonna change. There's a party and we ain't never gonna be invited. INT. MEMORIAL GYM — DAY Cager and Shed are dressed in their street clothes. Cager shooting baskets as Shed stands by, watching.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: You know, Scoop, sometimes I don’t even feel like going back out there again.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: (snaps ball at Shed) You can’t let them take basketball away. You can’t let them win.  74.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: (snaps ball back) I just don’t know how much more I can handle. I’m not like you. All brave.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Swee Pee, long as I known you, you been stronger than you think. Cager goes up for a twisting lay-up to the basket. Sudden stumbles. He catches himself, disoriented. Shed goes to h

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Scoop. You alright?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Nothin’! Nothin’, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Tell me what’s goin’ on! Cager tries to walk but crumples on the floor. Shed kneel

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Scoop? Willie? Willie, man. What's wrong!? Tell me what's wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins walks in the early darkness, with a tense look. INT. CAGER‘S DORM ROOM - SAME TIME Cager stands by his bed, folding his clothes into his suitcase. Just then Haskins comes inside.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Sure. What‘’s up?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: How long have you known you had a problem, Willie?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I started fainting in High School. Mamma took me to the doctor and he told me my heart was too big. Ain't that a kick?  75.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You're a damn fool, Cager. Why didn't you tell me? You could've died out there playin’ basketball like that.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: My whole life I only loved playin’ ball. I couldn’t play in high school. Had to work to support my sisters, but I never stopped playin’ on the street. ‘Cause to not play was like lettin’ somethin’ die in me. That was when Squeaky told me you had a place for me. You gave me my dream back. Gave me another chance.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I didn’t know all that, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: I can still play. This heart thing ain't nothin’. I lived with it this long, I plan on dyin' an old man with it. Let me play, Coach. I’ve gotta play.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Scoops. I’m-- not gonna be able play you anymore. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Coach. I gotta be out there. I’m not afraid!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's what I'm afraid of. I can't be responsible for what could happen, Willie. Much as I want you out there, I can't take the risk. I'm sorry. Cager looks down, crushed. Haskins puts a hand on his sho

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You're still on the team. We’re gonna need your courage-- we need your heart, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear SIMON AND GARFUNKEL, “The Sounds of Silence”. The Miners are getting on the bus. Mary stands with Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Don't worry, baby. I’ve wrestled bears, remember? I always come out alright.  76.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This time’s different, Don. There are things uglier and meaner than bears. Bobby Joe is in the crowd, looking for Tina. She appears a friend. She sees him and stops. But she turns away and off. Bobby Joe turns to the bus, looking conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players sit in silence, each lost in their own though CLOSE ON: Bobby Joe. He stares out the window, a strange, conflicted look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks with Moe, Ross, and the team as a THRONG of PEO comes toward them. LIGHTS are flashing. REPORTERS. ADOLPH RUPP, a short, intense man in his 60's, strides wi an entourage of coaches and his KENTUCKY WILDCATS. He has aura of celebrity about him as he wears a tight smile. Outside the window we see KENTUCKY'S own PRIVATE PLANE wi the Kentucky Wildcats emblem on the side. Rupp sees Haskins and the Miners and keeps a cool look. H stops as Haskins approaches. The Miners head to baggage c and the Wildcats to check-in. Haskins reaches out his han

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Coach Rupp. It’s an honor to meet you. I'm Don Haskins. I coach Texas--

dialogues.speaker: ADOLPH RUPP
dialogues.text: I know who you are. And I know your team.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you what it means to me to ‘meet you, Coach. I’ve learned a lot from watching you over the years.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: Last I looked at the polls, maybe too much.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: We still got a long ways to go. Rupp looks at Haskins’ team. Black and white faces stare ANGLE ON BOBBY JOE, ORSTEN, and FLOURNOY.  77.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Is that who I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: The man himself.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I don't think that white man likes us. ANGLE ON RUPP and HASKINS.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: That took a lot of nerve, signin’ all them colored boys.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I got the best players I could.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: You done a little more than that. You’re shakin’ things up, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Maybe things need a little shakin’.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: People don’t like things shook up. (intensely) Be careful, boy. You’re dealin’ with lives. Good people’s lives. (looking back at his team) Good luck. Maybe I‘1l see you down the line. Haskins watches as Rupp walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stands are jammed and the crowd is raucous.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. UNIVERSITY OF TULSA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe stands across from Haskins, looking nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Coach, I got something to tell you. And you ain’t gonna like it.  78.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What you do this time? Get a girl pregnant or something? Haskins waits. Finally Bobby Joe nods and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: No! Damn it! Bobby Joe! Damn it! You didn’t! What were you thinking?! Bobby Joe meets Haskins look. Haskins' jaw flexes, furiou

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Coach. I let you down. I let the team down. I know what the rules are. I know I can’t stay on the team.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: So you're just gonna walk away?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: No! I don’t want to! I mean, this team means everything to me. For the first time in my life I feel like I’m committed to something. But-- (beat) You told me I need to be a leader and a man. Well, that’s not just on the court. It has to be off it, too. I’m gonna marry her, Coach. I’m gonna be a father. Even if it means leaving the team.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Alright, okay. Let’s slow down a minute. Let’s think about this, Bobby Joe. No need to rush into anything. I mean, you know-- (trying to sound light) Well, there are probably a couple ways we can do this. Now you could leave the team and all that-- or-- I could-- hell, I could get you some housing. Nothin’ fancy. But I could help you-- get you set up. Bend the rules a little bit. Let you stay on the team and play.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: You'd do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Yeah. For you. And-- twenty three points a game... Eleven assists.  79.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: (grins) Thanks, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean I’m gonna let you forget this. You’re a pain in the ass, you’re a reckless, irresponsible, self- centered son-of-a-bitch-- (his voice softens) You're just like me. (beat) God, you get on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: (slaps him on the shoulder) I love you, too, Coach.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You get out there right now. Understand?
The players have been eavesdropping and jump back as the opens. Haskins looks at them. Bobby Joe just behind him.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What ya‘ll lookin’ at? They shake their heads mute. There is a SOUND above Haski head. He looks up. Baudoin crouches in the rafters, stark naked, his jock strap on his head. Haskins glowers, wry.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: And you wonder why I don’t play you more. (looking around) Now get on court. All of you. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players run into the arena. FANS cup their hands and shout, their faces twisted.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST TULSA FAN
dialogues.text: Oreo, you belong on the plantation!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND TULSA FAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Spook, it's huntin' season.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD TULSA FAN
dialogues.text: Hey, you better watch your black asses after the game. We know how to take care of runaway niggers.  80. Haskins gathers his players. Flournoy is rattled.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: One more honkey motherfucker shoots his mouth off, I'm going in the stands.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Why do you listen to them?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re talking about, Farm Boy!

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You think you're the only one getting crap shoved in your face? We’re traitors out there. Niggerlovers. We ain’t even white.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Cutit out! Both of you! Nobody reacts! You understand!? Nobody reacts to them! Now let's get going! IN THE STANDS... The number of BLACK FANS is growing. The hold signs and banners, “Go Miners!” and “We Love Our Tea GAME: The Miners struggle, spooked by the hostile crowd. Score is tied. Bobby Joe in-bounds to Shed, but Shed is nervous and a TULSA PLAYER picks him for a score.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What are you doin' out there, Shed!? Come on! Don’t back down! Find the open man! Get back on D! Block out! Baudoin tosses a bad pass to Bobby Joe and Tulsa steals t ball. The OFFICIAL calls a foul on Bobby Joe. Haskins ran

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What the hell s’that call?! Huh?! You got eyeballs in your head?! The official tells Haskins to back off. But he steps up, threatening. The official calls a TECHNICAL FOURL on Hask gesturing to stay back. Haskins takes another step. The OFFICIAL CALLS ANOTHER T. Ross pulls Haskins back to the bench. Haskins pulls himself free and walks to the other team’s of the court and sits down by the surprised Tulsa coach.

dialogues.speaker: TULSA COACH
dialogues.text: Uh-- Coach? You’re on the wrong--  81.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Hell. I like the view on this side better. INT. HASKINS HOME — SAME TIME Mary watches the game on TV with her four boys around her

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGEST BOY
dialogues.text: There's Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Is he mad? He looks mad.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s not mad. He’s just a-- stubborn, stubborn man, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Tulsa player trips Lattin at the basket. They fall. The REFEREE calls the foul on Lattin. Lattin charges in anger

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: He tripped me! He meant to do it! The referee now calls technical foul on Lattin.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Lattin. Take the bench!

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Coach!--

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Take the bench! Now! Lattin throws himself down on the bench, rattled. Haskins comes up to him, furious.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You never let your anger get the better of you again, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Coach, same thing happened to you. They're all against us! It’s bullshit out there!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You got nailed for a dirty play! It wasn’t fair! But this ain’t about fairness! We're not gonna get any breaks. You wanna be the best? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASKINS (cont'd) You gotta be better than them! You gotta hold yourself together! There may come a time when you can use all that anger. But I’1l tell you when that is. Understand me? Lattin looks at Haskins. He nods. LAST QUARTER: Time running out. Miners PULL AWAY from Tul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands in midst a pushing throng of reporters.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST REPORTER
dialogues.text: Coach Haskins, you and Kentucky, the number one team in the country, are now the only two undefeated teams... With one game to go in the regular season. Do you really think your team-- a team made up mostly of-- kids from the streets, can compete with a team like Adolph Rupp's?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS,
dialogues.text: I only care about making the tournament and advancing as far as we can. If we don't play better than we did tonight, that won't be very far.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: You've been playing your colored boys more each game. Are you at all concerned about whether the Negro ball player can handle the pressure of playing at a national level? HASKINS. No sir, I am not. As long as we play defense and score, we'll win basketball games.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD REPORTER
dialogues.text: People want to know. What kind of statement you are trying to make by playing so many colored boys?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I'm a basketball coach. I don't make statements. The reporters keep shouting questions but Haskins walks o  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players walk the dingy hallway. Shed and Cager open t door. Across, Flournoy, Worsley open their door. Flournoy goes inside, when he stops in his tracks, shocked. THE ROOM HAS BEEN DEFACED with ANIMAL BLOOD. Blood all ov the beds, cast out in buckets. Blood on the floor. On the walls. The words “Niggers Die” scrawled in blood. Lattin is behind Flournoy, whimpering, shaking.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Oh god, oh god... Worsley supports Lattin as he breaks down. In the bg we h

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Ross! Coach! Hurry! SHED AND CAGER’S ROOM. Furniture has been overturned. Blo covers floor and walls. Haskins stands looking with Ross.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Moe, get us checked out. Ross talk to management. How did this happen? He looks at the players. They stare at him in rage and sh

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Okay, listen. We're goin’ to Seattle tonight. We'll just get outta here. We'll be alright. Just remember that. Okay? We're okay. We just have to get outta here. We'll be okay... But his voice falters. The black players look back at him There is a strange look in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight is a somber, silent. Everyone staring ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players file in. A BELLMAN comes up to Flournoy. He reaches out to take his bag. Flournoy pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I take my own bag, thanks. He walks off. Haskins watches the other black players fol  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands looking out over the bay. Ross comes up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What you standin’ here for?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don't know, Ross. Sometimes I wonder-~ what am I getting these guys into?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: A dream you promised them. That’s what.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: My whole life I’ve thought of nothin’ but winnin’. And I got these boys winnin’ alright. But-- is it for them-- this whole thing? Or is it just for me?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: It’s for everybody. Everybody gains.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: But at what cost? It's hard enough to play the game at this level, but to ask them to withstand all that-- how can I ask them to take on all that goes with it?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You done the right thing, Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Ross. I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shed, Orsten, Worsley, Cager, Lattin and Flournoy sit at table. They have a silent, locked in look. Togo and Armstrong walk in, with Myers and Palacio. Togo Armstrong move to the table of black players. Nobody look

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You got some room there?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you take another table?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Fine. Come on, guys. Let's go.  85. Togo follows them, glancing back at the black players, up Armstrong indicates to Palacio and Myers. They sit togeth glancing back, talking amongst themselves.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. SEATTLE The players stand apart from each other. Haskins eyes the crowd. Ross paces. Moe reads his roster of starters.

dialogues.speaker: JUD MILTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With number one Kentucky losing yesterday, the Miracle Miners have a chance to do the seemingly impossible in their final game of the regular season... thrill the hearts of their dedicated El Paso fans by becoming the nation's only undefeated team and rise to the top of the polls over Adolph Rupp’s fabled Wildcats. SERIES OF IMAGES: Lattin in against Seattle. He loses the tip. Immediately, the players play divided. Flournoy igno Armstrong’s signal and passes to Orsten, but Orsten loses ball. Haskins paces, watching them struggle. It’s clear t team has become fractured. All of the outside and interna pressures are crippling them, IN THE CROWD, there are groups of BLACK FANS, on their fe cheering, groaning, reacting to the Miners losing game. ON COURT, Bobby Joe passes to Shed. Armstrong is too slow two Seattle BIG MEN suffocate Shed and cause a three seco violation. Bobby Joe lays into Armstrong who walks away. Seattle nails jumpers over Orsten and Worsley. Bobby Joe' MAN beats him off the dribble. The HALF-TIME BUZZER SOUND The MINERS ARE BEHIND: 36 TO 39. Ross throws his towel do as Bobby Joe fumbles a dribble and throws out of bounds.

dialogues.speaker: JUD MILTON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's hard to say what has got the undefeated Miners struggling as much as they are today. But they seem to have lost their shooting touch, particularly Bobby Joe Hill. He may be ‘No Sweat’ Hill, but he’s sweating now. LATER: Haskins is on the bench, frustrated. At another sc for Seattle, Ross jumps off the bench, yelling at referee as he tosses his towel in the air. It lands on the head o REFEREE, who throws him out of the game.  86. LAST MINUTES: Miners make a final push. The teams trade baskets. Bobby Joe is fouled. Miners down by ONE. TWO SEC to go. Bobby Joe steps to the line.

dialogues.speaker: MILTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Texas Western's perfect season comes down to Bobby Joe Hill. The Texas Western star has struggled all night, but he can redeem himself with two free throws now. Bobby gets into position. He sets and fires. The ball SWI INSIDE THE RIM, POPS OUT and FALLS TO THE GROUND. Haskins turns away. The BUZZER. Seattle rushes the floor. The Min stand stunned. Bobby Joe looks shell-shocked. FINAL SCORE: SEATTLE 74. TEXAS WESTERN 73. The team files out as a TV ANNOUNCER speaks into the came

dialogues.speaker: SPORTS ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: The Cinderella Miners had a chance at a perfect Season and a shot at unseating powerhouse Kentucky for the number one spot in the nation, but tonight’s loss drops them down to number three and raises the questions again about whether this team, and its unorthodox line up, is a legitimate contender for the NCAA championship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are getting out of their jerseys. There is a tense, divided silence in the room. Haskins comes inside.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You stunk out there! Squeaky could've played better D than you did tonight! And where the pick's Shed? You were runnin' scared just like the old Shed! Maybe y’all thought that undefeated record means something. Maybe you thought you could sit back and waltz your way into the goddamn tournament. Well, I got news for you. You keep playing like you did tonight, you might as well unpack your bags, ‘cause you ain't goin' nowhere!

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: You think basketball’s everything, Coach. But that’s easy for you to say. You don’t have redneck crackers getting in your face all the time.  87.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I know. You don’t get it. None of you. You're all the same.

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: Hold on, man. Not all white people are like those people, man.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, who’s different?!

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: I’m different! All of us here!

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: That’s a nice rap, man. But you don’t have people breakin’ into your room. Attackin’ you like they did Shedyman. What do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: You think we haven't had heat come down on us? You think it hasn‘t been hard being on this team?

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t be doin’ me any favors.

dialogues.speaker: BAUDOIN
dialogues.text: You don’t know what it’s like to have to take a back seat for you all the time. It’s like we don’t even count.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Yeah, and we have to pull you along like some weight around our necks.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: Stop it! You stop this right now! The players push against each other. Shed looks at Haskin

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Coach, we don’t wanna win if it means being treated like dirt. It’s not worth it. If that’s what it takes, we don’t wanna do this anymore.  88.

dialogues.speaker: TOGO
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You guys wanna bag the season with the tournament about to start?! We worked too hard to quit now.

dialogues.speaker: , FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Who worked so hard? Who takes all the shit out there to get it done?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Last time I checked we were a team.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: (shoving Armstrong) Get outta my face, Farmer!

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: No. Stop it, man.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Peckerheads! Settle down, now!

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You're always talkin’ to us like we just gotta go along with the program. Ignore all that stuff. Just take it. You don’t know what it’s like! None of you! There is a long silence. Haskins looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: For a whole season we've been a team. This is the first time I’ve seen you break apart. And over what? Because a few in this room have forgotten why they’re here. Haskins looks at every one of the black players.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: It wasn’t so you would just warm the bench of a white team. It wasn’t so you could make the plays while others got the eredit. It was because you wanted a chance to show what you could do on a basketball court, no matter what your color, no matter what some cracker coach or some white trash fan said. It was so you could stand on that center stripe after spilling your blood and have the world say-- there goes a man. There goes a basketball player!  89.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: But, Coach, they've taken our dignity away. What kind of man lets his dignity get taken away? HASKINS. Dignity? No one can take something away from you that you don’t give them. Your dignity is inside you. And no one can take it away. You can only give it up. (he looks each in the eye) It’s your choice. You can walk away, or walk through the fire and grab it all. But iff you walk away, you’1l never know if you could've stood on that center line. ON the players’ silent faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERAS FLASH. Miners shove through a POLICE LINE, a HOST CROWD, pushing, YELLING EPITHETS. An NBC TV ANNOUNCER spe

dialogues.speaker: FIRST NBC ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The NCAA Tournament gets off to a rip roaring start as the Cincinnati Bearcats take on the upstart Texas Western Miners...

dialogues.speaker: MIDWEST FINALS
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. KANSAS Fans yell. School bands play. The clock is readied. The N ANNOUNCER looks into a camera. FIRST ANNOUNCER (CONT’D) While the Texas Western club has certainly turned heads across the country with its roster of seven Negro players it’s safe to say that Don Haskins’ noble experiment should end tonight against the seven time Missouri Valley Conference champs.  90.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's right, Bob! The combination of a weak schedule and the fact that Haskins is relying on Negro players who-- while great pure athletes-- lack the leadership, the intellect and heart to play basketball at a championship level, will likely spell an early exit from the tournament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long line of ticket buyers is cued up. A handful of the FACES IN THE WAITING CROWD are BLACK. White people eye th INT. MINERS’ LOCKER ROOM - SAME TIME Haskins and the Miners huddle, heads bowed and hands clas

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: Lord. We've been pulled at. Torn. We've doubted ourselves as men and as players. Thank you for keeping us together. See us through, no matter what the obstacles, no matter how high the mountain. Amen. The team CHEERS and rushes out. Flournoy and Armstrong ar the last ones left. They exchange an awkward look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A capacity crowd in the arena. A lone tall, BLACK PLAYER Kansas, JO-JO WHITE, warms up with his all white team.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O. CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Led by All-American Jo-Jo White and the biggest front line in the tournament, the number six Jayhawks are, with Duke, the odds-on favorite to challenge Adolph Rupp and the Kentucky Wildcats for college basketball's holy grail! The MINERS ENTER THE ARENA and EXPLODE into SHOWTIME as B Joe does dazzling passes, Shed streaks for a lay-in and Lattin JAMS ONE HOME. A ripple of shock passes through th crowd. Flournoy sees Jo-Jo White’s look of surprise.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Brother looks lonely.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. He does.  91. Haskins stands on the floor clapping his hands and exhort his players as Cager, fully suited up, comes out of the tunnel and onto the court. Haskins catches him in his arm

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: What the hell you doin’, Scoops?

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: I gotta play, Coach. I gotta play. In whatever way. I gotta play.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Damn it, Cager. I’ll play you. Only off the bench, five minutes at time. No exceptions. Cager grabs a ball and drives for a lay-up and SCORES. Th MINER FANS LEAP to their feet and CHEER. GAME: KANSAS FANS CHANT the Kansas fight song as Bobby Jo streaks up court against JO-JO WHITE. He snaps a pass to Orsten who launches a 20-footer that slashes through the Haskins pounds his program in his hands and barks command Jo-Jo White brings the ball up. The game is tied at 40. H tosses the ball into one of Kansas’ FORWARDS, a big, nast looking farm kid. As Armstrong moves in to put a body on the Kansas Forward smirks into Armstrong's face.

dialogues.speaker: KANSAS FORWARD
dialogues.text: You shower with all them niggers?

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You can just go to hell! The' Forward elbows Armstrong’s gut. Armstrong doubles ov

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That was flagrant! I want a T! Kansas scores. Shed charges to the Kansas Forward, enrage

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: What was that shit, huh?!

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD
dialogues.text: Get outta my face, Eightball. Shed suddenly unloads a vicious RIGHT HOOK, dropping the Kansas giant. The referee jumps in and signals Shed out o the game. Haskins screams at the official. Lattin looks between the bloodied Kansas player and Shed, impressed.  92.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Way to go, Shadow! Shed leaves to a CHORUS of BOOS, passing Haskins, who gri

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Shed, you wild man. LATER IN GAME. Game is close by two points. Bobby Joe is getting everybody, Cager, Worsley, Lattin and Orsten, int the action. But Kansas and Jo-Jo White stay with them. The Jayhawks bring the ball up, less than a minute to pla Haskins looks at the score. Jayhawks ahead 81-80. It look but Bobby Joe PICKS Kansas‘ Center and LOBS a pass to Cag who flies through the air and scores. The crowd goes wild

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Willie Cager saves the day! Refusing to go down, Texas Western has beaten the powerful Jayhawks! FINAL SCORE: TEXAS WESTERN 81, KANSAS 80. The Kansas fans stand silent, in a state of utter shock.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In what can only be described as the game of the year the Texas Western Miners continue to defy the odds and the wisdom of the experts... - - as they win the Midwest Championship and move on to Maryland and the Final Four!... As 8,000 spectators file out, the black Miner fans chant Number 1!", holding signs: “TWC: Maryland, Here We Come!!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, Bob, whatever else happens, the Miners seem to be playing for something more than just the final score. Something bigger than basketball. And Don Haskins-- he looks like a shoe-in for ‘Coach Of The Year’ honors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don walks past players reading a “Sport Illustrated” head “Breaking the Barriers”. A crowd of rowdy BOOSTERS AND FA are also on the plane. Haskins shakes hands as Wade Richa comes up, hand outheld, “Sports Illustrated” in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: Don Haskins, you ol’ sonofabitch! Have you read it already? Have you?!  93.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I have read it.

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: It says here-- ‘the selfless support of Texas Western’s booster, Wade Richardson, which has made this break-out team’s rise a true phenomenon in the sports world.’

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: They got you down, sir. Didn’t they?

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: Hell, Don Haskins. You forget all that stuff I said before. I’m sellin’ more dinettes than the last four years combined. You ol’ sonofabitch! You really done it! We’re goin’ to the Final Four!! Listen, I wanted to ask you a favor. Richardson grabs his 12 year-old son and pushes him forwa

dialogues.speaker: WADE RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: I’d sure appreciate it if Wade Jr. could sit with y’all durin’ the games.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: (beat; peers at Junior) You a basketball fan, Junior?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I sure am, sir!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You can sit with us anytime, boy. Junior beams. Haskins pats him on the shoulder and walks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins and his players, dressed in suits and ties, push through NEWSPAPERMEN and PHOTOGRAPHERS, into a posh hotel white HECKLERS taunt them from behind a police barricade.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST HECKLER
dialogues.text: You come to the wrong part of the country, nigger boys!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND HECKLER
dialogues.text: This is the South. We don’t cotton to no uppity coloreds messin’ with our basketball! Worsley looks at Cager as they pass to safety.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Where's Malcolm's black ass when you need him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rupp sits beneath a banner: “Sports Writers of America”. HOST addresses two hundred dinner guests, mostly reporter

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: It is my great privilege to announce this year's winner of the 1966 “NCAA Coach of the Year...”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins sits eating dinner with Mary, watching the teleca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOST (CONT’D) Winner of five National Championships, on his way to a sixth, I give you the Baron of Bluegrass, Adolph Rupp! The crowd bursts into applause as Rupp waves to the crowd INT. SHED’S ROOM - SAME TIME The players watch as Rupp is handed an impressive trophy.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: That’s Coach’s trophy, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REPORTER rises and takes the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: A few questions, Mr. Rupp!

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: What, you lure an ol’ man here with wine and food just so you can ask a few more questions?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Indulge me, Mr. Rupp. More and more, we are seeing Negro players on teams. How is it in your nearly 40 years at Kentucky, you‘ve never recruited a single black player?  95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the Miners, black and white, stop eating, mid-mouthfu

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: Anybody can go to New York City and find five colored boys who can jump. But basketball is about a hell of a lot more than runnin’ and jumpin’. It takes intelligence, skill and heart.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: So you would never~- under any circumstance-- recruit a Negro?

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: (grins cocky) Last I checked, I won four National titles without one. Way I figure, I must be doin’ somethin’ right. As Rupp's admiring crowd LAUGHS and APPLAUDS, the Texas Western players look at each other, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins and the team sit silent, heading for COLE FIELD HOUSE, home of the Final Four. Over the radio, they hear:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: While today's semifinal game between Texas Western and Utah is widely seen as a battle for third place in the tournament, the arrival of Don Haskins’ Texas Western team has stirred up the basketball world, particularly south of the Mason Dixon line... The bus turns toward Cole Field House, as white-faced RED sprint forward, tossing huge CHUNKS OF WATERMELON, landin a violent thuds and leaving ominous red streaks on the wi

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: I know we’re supposed to use our anger, Coach, but sometimes I--- The players see an astonishing sight, pulling up to the entrance: a THRONG of BLACK MEN, WOMEN and CHILDREN, line entrance to Cole Field House, chanting “Go Miners! GO MIN

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: -- Sweet Jesus!  96. The white Miners look at their black teammates and see ho moved they are by the spontaneous show of solidarity. Stepping out the black players receive CHEERS and slaps o the backs. An OLD BLACK WOMAN steps up to the huge Lattin

dialogues.speaker: OLD WOMAN
dialogues.text: I come all the way from Macon. I don’t watch no basketball. But when you play-- you be playin’ for all of us. You understand me? You be playin’ for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands at a chalkboard, diagrammed with plays.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: You think Jo-Jo White was tough, tonight we’ve got the best player in the tournament to deal with. If we stop Jerry Chambers, we stop Utah. Give me a circle. clasping hands with players) Tonight, you’re playing in a special building. The ghost of champions are everywhere in this goddamn place. I just want you to know-- you belong in this building. No matter what anybody says. You belong here. On three! Bobby Joe looks at Haskins and then at his teammates.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Let's get this for Coach Haskins. Coach of the Year!

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: For Coach!! As the players run out, Haskins stands speechless, moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venerable Cole Field House is packed to the gills. Photographers CAMERAS FLASH from behind each basket.

dialogues.speaker: NCAA NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. UTAH TV CAMERAS cover the action from all angles as Flournoy t to keep with Utah’s only black player, JERRY CHAMBERS.  97.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Texas Western is getting a piece of its own medicine tonight as it tries to corral consensus All American Jerry Chambers... The 6'4” Forward is unstoppable as he blows PAST FLOURNOY a running hook. The crowd, mostly pro Utah, EXPLODES. Haskins looks up at the scoreboard which shows the Miners trailing 35-33 and losing momentum fast.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look at Chambers! Such raw athletic ability! He's the perfect compliment to his white teammates who provide the leadership and poise necessary for victory. Haskins looks down the bench, trying to find an answer fo Chambers before he causes more harm. He looks at Cager.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Scoops-- get in there. Cager runs out and Flournoy heads for the bench.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Coach. I can’t keep up with him. Haskins watches Bobby Joe dump a pass off to Orsten who c the lane and scores. The Utes get the ball back to Chambe who scores easily on Cager. He is jtoo quick and powerful LATE IN THE GAME. The Texas Western fans watch, bleakly, Chambers lights up the net with another 20 footer.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The Miners of Texas Western are on the verge of elimination as neither Nevil Shed or Willie Cager can stop Jerry Chambers.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That‘s right. Chambers has lit the Miners up for 28 tonight. At this point it looks as if Don “The Bear” Haskins has finally run out of answers. Haskins looks at the clock: Fourteen minutes remain. Mine down by eight. Haskins, desperate, scans his bench.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Armstrong-- can you stop that kid?  98.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Coach, I may just be a hog farmer. But one thing I can do is cover a man. Haskins sends Armstrong out. Chambers looks at Armstrong surprised. He takes the ball into the lane, but Armstrong right at him, smothering him. Off balance, Chambers unloa ball which is picked off by Worsley who streaks in for tw The CLOCK drains away and the Miners start chanting “FARM FARMER, FARMER!!!”. Chambers gets the ball, but Armstrong suffocates him, lays his body out to take charges, knocks ball away and dives on the hardwood, getting the loose ba INT. THELMA’S STEAKHOUSE - MISSOURI - SAME TIME Jerry's father sits with several FARMERS, watching a television over the bar, rooting for the game, excited.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG FATHER
dialogues.text: Do you see that?! That’s my boy! That’s my boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miners blitzkrieg, filling the net with outside shots Orsten, daredevil drives by Bobby Joe, and slams by Latti As the final BUZZER SOUNDS, the scoreboard showing TEXAS WESTERN 85, UTAH 78, the Miners lift Armstrong on their shoulders. He grins, astonished at the attention. Haskins being hugged by Moe, nodding his approval at the players.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No fans, it’s not a mistake. The scoreboard is working. Texas Western's improbable season continues as they beat Utah and advance to the championship of college basketball! Flournoy passes Armstrong with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Way to play, man. Armstrong looks surprised. Filing off the court, Bobby Jo and other black Miners are stopped by Jerry Chambers, swe running down his face.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERS
dialogues.text: Go all the way, man. Take down that championship net.  99. INT. HASKINS’ HOTEL ROOM - THAT NIGHT Don sits with Mary watching Adolph Rupp exhort his player during the Kentucky-Duke semi-final.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There’s no doubt that the real NCAA final is tonight as perennial NCAA powerhouse Duke goes up against Adolph Rupp’s four time National Champion Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Guess we might as well not show up tomorrow. I’m just a coach from Enid, Oklahoma. What was I thinkin’ of?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t talk nonsense, Don. That’s not true. Don shrugs and takes a drink as Kentucky heads to victory

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O. CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kentucky’ s All-American guard Louis Dampier brings the ball up. Spots Pat Riley, the Wildcats’ leading scorer, in the corner. He shoots! It’s good! Kentucky is on it’s way to an unprecedented fifth National Championship!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish brunch for the wives of coaches, team boosters a tournament VIPs. Mary sits at a table, alone. Kentucky wi in chiffon and elaborate hats, make a startling contrast Mary who is dressed in a simple, but attractive red dress One of the KENTUCKY BOOSTER WIVES sips a Mint Julep and t in shocked tones to her fellow southern friends.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KENTUCKY WIFE
dialogues.text: It’s just awful that they're letting that team full of Negroes play.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KENTUCKY WIFE
dialogues.text: How that horrible man would be willing to play those coloreds. It’s a disgrace to the tournament, that’s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KENTUCKY WIFE
dialogues.text: Well, they'll be handed a lesson tomorrow they won't soon forget. (looking at Mary) And where are you from, sweetheart?  100.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: El Paso, Texas. I’m married to that horrible man you were just talking about. The women turn white and quickly move off. A kind faced w in her sixties comes up to Mary.

dialogues.speaker: KIND FACED WOMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to them. They haven‘t the sense they were born with.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: No, I guess they haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: KIND FACED WOMAN
dialogues.text: (extending her hand; smile) My name is Esther. Esther Rupp. Mary looks surprised and takes her hand, smiling slowly. her eyes grow troubled again and trail back to the others they chatter snidely between themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTERS and PHOTOGRAPHERS pack a crowded press room. Haskins and Moe head to the interview stand under a banne that reads “NCAA National Championship”. Suddenly Adolph appears beside him. Haskins extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Coach-- I had a funny feeling I'd be seeing you again. Rupp looks at Haskins. Instead of the open, amiable man a the airport, he has his game face on.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
