dialogues.text: That right? Well, enjoy it while you're here, fella. Ain’t gonna see it again. Haskins is stung by Rupp’s naked gamesmanship. He stands beside him at the interview stand, his jaw tight. FLASHBU BLIND him as REPORTERS fire off their questions.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Haskins-- How do you plan to stop Louis Dampier and Pat Riley?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: How are they gonna stop Bobby Joe Hill and David Lattin?  101.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: Sounds like the coach is pretty excited ‘bout those wins he got out west. But at Kentucky, we don’t much worry ‘bout the man in the other uniform. We just play Kentucky basketball. A SECOND REPORTER rises and looks at Rupp.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND REPORTER
dialogues.text: Coach, you've been around this game a long time. You are college basketball. How do you feel about the racial make-up of the Texas Western team?

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: You mean those Texans from the wide open spaces of New York, Detroit and Indiana? LAUGHTER. Then Rupp’s eyes fill with ominous hatred.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I learned this game at the feet of Dr. Naismith in the cradle of basketball. I've been coachin’ it near on forty years and the one thing I know is this: there ain’t no five niggers that can beat five white boys in the great game of basketball! You hear me? No damn niggers! So you write that down. Put it on the front page. And you tell them you heard it from Adolph Rupp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands outside the arena, a lone figure on the street, staring up at the HUGE BILLBOARD of a smiling COA RUPP and his Wildcats lit up over the empty parking lot o Cole Field House. Moe stands at a distance, listening as Haskins talks. Haskins’ voice is hoarse.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: He’s a great coach. Greatest there ever was. I always admired him. Measured myself against him. If I could just be like Coach Rupp. The big man. Moe looks down, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: But maybe-- maybe the big man’s still got a thing to learn about basketball. About boys that are playin’ for more than just a damn championship.  102. He turns to Moe.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Call the players, Moe. Tell them to meet me at the arena. Now. INT. ARMSTRONG AND SHED’S ROOM - SAME TIME Armstrong and Shed lie in darkness, staring at the ceilin

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You asleep, Shadow?

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Naw. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: My dad called. Says everyone in town's goin’ to Thelma’s Steakhouse to watch the game tonight. He said he was proud of me. He ain’t never said that before. I never thought I’d hear him say that.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: You’1l show him, Farmer. You will... My folks are drivin’ down to the game with Willie’s parents. My old man’s comin’, too. He was always a baseball fan, but I think he’s finally likin’ basketball.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: No kiddin’, Shadow? I'll be. INT. FLOURNOY AND LATTIN’S ROOM Flournoy is wide awake, as Lattin tries to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: Talked to my folks tonight. They’re taking some savings and flyin’ out for the game.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: That's nice, Flo, but there's a game tomorrow and I'd like to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: You know-- I almost didn’t come here because of a piece of pie. I was ready to give up every dream I ever had because that man ate my piece of pie. Harry smiles to himself, the first we’ve seen, and turns Lattin who is snoring soundly.  103. INT. WORSLEY AND CAGER‘'S ROOM - SAME Worsley sits in bed, arms behind his head. Cager is dozin

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: I never thought I’d care this much. It was always just a game to me. Just a way out to somewhere else. I never thought it could change anything. But now-- feels like a lot more than a game.

dialogues.speaker: CAGER
dialogues.text: I know what you mean, brother. Feels like my whole life right now. The PHONE RINGS. Worsley looks at Cager. Worsley picks it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orsten looks at Bobby Joe, whose eyes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: How can you sleep, dude?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: I ain’t sleepin’. I’m thinkin’ about stuff-- about Tina-- how much I love her and all that.

dialogues.speaker: ORSTEN
dialogues.text: Yo, man! We playin’ for the National Championship and you thinkin’ about some mushy stuff?! I’m going to sleep in Big Daddy D's room, you keep on like that. At that moment, the door opens and Worsley looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: WORSLEY
dialogues.text: Coach wants to see us as Cole Field House. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands across from seven sleepy black players in eerily empty gym. His face is full of angry emotion.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: My whole life, all I ever cared about was winning. Making my teams the best they could be. I never cared about who I had to play, long as my players had the best chance to win. But all that changed today. (looking at each player) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASKINS (cont'd) It changed because Coach Rupp doesn’t think you belong here simply because of the color of your skin. He thinks because you look different than him you're going to lose the National Championship. Now from what I know about you boys, I know that’s a load’a bull. And I intend to show that good ‘ol boy just what I think. The players look at each other, a charge going through th

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: So, I've made a decision tonight. Haskins face is filled with deep emotion. His eyes dart.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I’'m only going to play you tomorrow in the final game. Just you. There is a stunned silence among the players.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: It’s your game. I’ve made that decision because there’s--... Haskins voice cracks. He gets himself under control.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: -- there’s more to this game than just winning. The players look shocked and emotional.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That’s-~ that’s all I had to say. (beat) You show them tomorrow. The world’s watchin’ you. He turns and walks out, his players watching him go, stun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miners bus pulls up. A crowd of KENTUCKY FANS PRESSES on police barricades. Miners step from the bus, with duffle They endure a BARRAGE of ugly RACIAL EPITHETS. A corpulen woman SPITS on LATTIN. Hooded KLANSMEN threaten Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: KLANSMAN
dialogues.text: You want to be the first white man lynched since the Civil War-- you go on and play them niggers.  105. Haskins and the Miners walk past, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman Carr sits with kitchen staff and friends, gathered around a TV, watching the images we have just seen, excit

dialogues.speaker: CARR
dialogues.text: Come on. Turn it up. Turn it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flournoy’s parents push through a throng of people, arms around each other, to a security line at the press entran Waiting groupies and fans crowd around. A GUARD stops the Mr. Flournoy pulls out his wallet and identification. FLOURNOY'S FATHER . We're the parents of one of the Miners. Flournoy. You have a pass for us? The security guard checks his clipboard as people stare f all around. The guard nods and allows them through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team is getting dressed into Miner orange and white, Ross stands at the chalk board and addresses the players.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Kentucky's the fastest team in the country so Coach wants to go with speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe stands with Haskins.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna do this, Coach? You get only seven players. One of them has a heart condition. They’re gonna be more tired. You're breaking up chemistry. You been winning a whole season. You change your line up and you may gamble it all away!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I know that, Squeaky. But first time in my life-- this ain’t a gamble. I made my decision.

dialogues.speaker: MOE
dialogues.text: ..- What about the others?  106. Haskins holds his look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins comes inside and reads off the starting five.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Here’s today’s starting line up: Bobby Joe and Worsley, you're at guard. Big Daddy, you're at center. Orsten and Flournoy, you’re at Forward. Shadow, I’1l bring you and Scoops off the bench. The black players nod, avoiding the eyes of the white players. Haskins looks at his white players.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Some of you may wonder if you’re gonna play today-- and I wanted to tell you that this-- it wasn’t an easy decision. Maybe it’s not even the right decision, but I-- you won’t be playing today. He looks at each player. They look back at him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I feel it’s the only right thing to do. I hope you understand it. The white players look at each other. Armstrong comes for

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Coach--

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: I know what this means to you, Jerry-- I know what it means to all of you...

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: No, Coach. You don’t have to explain. (looking at the black players) We all heard what Coach Rupp said. He looks at Baudoin, Myers, Palacio, Togo. They nod. The whites stand together filled with emotion, facing the bla players. Armstrong looks at each black player.

dialogues.speaker: ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: You go out there and beat those boys, you hear? We got folks watchin’ back home. This is your moment. You go out there and do us proud, man. Do us proud.  107. Armstrong holds the game ball in his hands. He tosses it Flournoy. Flournoy catches it. He looks stunned. The othe black players look at their white teammates, deeply moved One by one the other white players reach out their hands a handshake, Myers, Togo, Baudoin, and Palacio. Emotional the black players shake in brotherhood. Flournoy, tears i his eyes, pulls Armstrong into an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A capacity CROWD of 14,000 fills Cole Field House. PHOTOGRAPHERS and TELEVISION CAMERAS fill the side court. teaming crowd, almost all Kentucky fans, wave Confederate flags as the Miners warm up.

dialogues.speaker: FINAL GAME
dialogues.text: TEXAS WESTERN vs. KENTUCKY IN THE CROWD...FLOURNOY’S, SHED’S AND WILLIE CAGER’S PARE are all very excited, craning to glimpse their boys. MARY sits court side. Haskins and Moe come from the locke room. He glimpses her, excuses himself to Moe and goes to

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'm so nervous, Don.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Mary, I wanted to say-- I know I haven’t been the best husband or father--

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It’s alright, Don. I understand it. You go out there and give them hell, alright? You show them. You show them. She kisses him. Haskins smiles at her, moved. ON THE FLOOR... the OFFICIAL SCORER calls for the two coa to meet at the scorers table to exchange their opening li as the NBC BROADCAST TEAM winds up their national audienc

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Texas Western, the Cinderella team from El Paso, Texas, takes on the Baron of Bluegrass and his Kentucky Wildcats for the Championship of College Basketball!  108. Haskins meets Rupp at the scorer’s table. They pull out t line-up cards.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, Don Haskins’ Miners are going to need more that a golden slipper to beat Rupp’s Runts. Led by Louis Dampier and the high scoring Pat Riley, they play with a speed, poise and intelligence no team of mostly-- how would you say-- raw street players can hope to match. Rupp looks at Don as he hands his line up over.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: Didn’t mean to school you the other day, kid.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: That's all right, Coach. We all have things to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black players stand alone together, looking out at th crowd in the stadium, waiting. The SOUNDS of the CHEERING the BAND FILTER IN as we linger on each of their faces. T looks are somber, serious, determined. Cager flexes his jaw. Lattin’s chest rises and falls heav Shed blinks his nervousness back. Orsten stares, focused. Bobby Joe nods to himself, getting ready, as they all sta out at the moment ahead of them. In the stadium the Wildcats finish their precision drills BUZZER SOUNDS. The ANNOUNCER comes on. The players exchan looks. Bobby Joe breathes out.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: Let’s do it, brothers. He puts his fist in the middle and the others place their fists over his and raise them in a ROAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights dim and the STADIUM ANNOUNCER reads the starti line up for Kentucky. The FANS go crazy, their BAND launc into a frenzied version of “DIXIE”.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now the starting line up of the Texas Western Miners!  109. A HUGE CONTINGENT of MINERS FANS, including Mary, Flourno Cager's and Shed's parents rise and CHEER.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM ANNOUNCER, (V.O. CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At Guard, out of Detroit Michigan, Bobby Joe Hill! The other guard, from New York City, Willie Worsley! At center, from Houston, David “Big Daddy” Lattin!... One after another, the BLACK PLAYERS WALK OUT ON THE COUR The crowd sits shocked. Dumbfounded, Rupp looks down at Haskins’ line-up card.

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM ANNOUNCER, (V.0O. CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At Forward, out of Gary Indiana, Harry Flournoy! And at the other Forward, Orsten ‘Little 0’ Artis!! The BLACK FANS, led by Flournoy's, Cager and Shed’s paren rise and CHEER their heads off. The Kentucky crowd is ici silent. We CUT TO the announcer’s stand.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: In an unprecedented move, Coach Haskins has fielded an all black team, the first in NCAA Championship history!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: He seems to be trying to make a point, Harry. What, I don’t know. As the Kentucky fans recover, growing more riled than eve the band strikes up “DIXIE” again and Confederate flags f the arena. Don pulls his team into a circle. He looks at them, his face filled with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: When this tournament began, I told you that you had one choice. To walk away or stand on the center stripe and know that you played like a man. To run and hide or step up and have the whole world say, now there goes a basketball player. (beat) That center stripe is here. It’s forty minutes away from each and every one of you. Take it. Make it yours! On three!!! Moved by his words, the players, Black and White, join ha

dialogues.speaker: MINERS
dialogues.text: Goll!  110. As the Miners take the floor, Haskins pulls Lattin aside.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: David, you remember I told you there would be a time when I want you to use your anger. Well, now is the time. When you get that ball I want you to flush it as hard as you can. Understand me? Let them know that you're here!

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: (pumped up) Nothin’ to worry ‘bout, Coach. Big Daddy D’s in the house!

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Bobby Joe. Remember Dampier’s got great hands. If you try to take the ball, he‘'ll burn you and score.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE
dialogues.text: (grins) Is that on order? The Miners take the floor as DAMPIER, RILEY and other WILDCATS come out. They line up for the OPENING TIP. Latt faces Pat Riley, his face full of furious energy.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There can be little doubt among fans here and across the country that Kentucky’s superior speed and shooting will carry the day. The BALL goes INTO the AIR. Lattin rises up, his eyes on fire, and SWATS the ball to Bobby Joe. With the All Ameri Dampier on him, Bobby rockets up the court. Tossing the b to Worsley, he uses Lattin for a pick, and cuts into the lane. Lattin fires a pass to Hill who goes in for the lay and SCORES. The crowd reacts, subdued. Startled by Hill's speed, Dampier takes the inbound pass rifles it to the Kentucky center, JARACZ, who quickly pun it out to Riley at the top of the key. Faking Flournoy to left, he drives around him, straight into the key. As he lifts off for what looks like a sure bucket, Lattin SUDDE appears, his body arching upward and his hand SLAPPING th shot away like a harmless fly. Stunned, Riley crashes to the floor and the referee calls FOUL on Lattin, Big Daddy shoots Riley a menacing look.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: You playin’ in my house now, Riley.  111. ON THE COURT, a shaken Riley HITS one of his two free thr and Flournoy grabs the REBOUND. Hitting Hill in stride, t blazing Guard turns Dampier around and, spotting Lattin n the basket, drills a bullet pass through several Wildcats Lattin. Lattin turns and looks. This is his moment. He go and SLAMS a MONSTER DUNK over a startled, ducking Riley.

dialogues.speaker: LATTIN
dialogues.text: Motha Fuckers-- get out my way! THE BLACK FANS are on their feet, crazy, CHEERING. Togo l off the bench, whipping his towel like a mad man. Shed pa Riley, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: Hey man, you looked like the brother's shadow out there. Riley tries to ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The big center for Texas Western is dominating the smaller Kentucky Wildcat line up so far. But the real test is whether the upstart Miners can stop Dampier. Once the All American gets going, nobody can stop him! In a quick succession of plays, all directed by Dampier, Wildcats score on a fast break to Jaracz, Riley hits a ju from the corner and Dampier nails an 18 footer. MARY AND THE OTHER MINER FANS, have their hearts in their throats. The scoreboard shows Kentucky ahead 8-5. Flournoy twists his knee, and limps to the sideline, glum

dialogues.speaker: FLOURNOY
dialogues.text: I can't go, Coach. Haskins pats him on the back and looks at Cager.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Get in there, Scoops. And tell Bobby Joe to get on Dampier! The Miners immediately respond. Orsten hits a 23 footer a Bobby Joe drives for the SCORE. Feeling the pressure, Dam brings the ball up against Orsten. Crossing the mid-court stripe, Dampier turns, changing his dribble from his righ left hand-- but before he can, Bobby Joe SWEEPS IN OUT OF NOWHERE and KNOCKS THE BALL AWAY. Streaking down court, h goes in for a layup and SCORES!  112.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hill makes an incredible steal for a score from Dampier! A frustrated Dampier brings the ball back up for the Wildcats.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: What happened to Dampier’s famous Fort Knox hands, Harry? Dampier crosses down midcourt and turns to his left when, replay of the last play, Bobby Joe PICKS HIM CLEAN again takes it to SCORE. As the crowd reacts with shock.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hill steals again! Holy Christmas, we have a game tonight, folks. We have a game! Togo is on his feet, SCREAMING, CHEERING, red in the face hyperventilating himself into a frenzy when his eyes sudd roll back and he PASSES OUT on the floor. Ross rushes ove slaps him in the face, bringing him back to consciousness AN EXCITED HASKINS exhorts his troops: Hill, Lattin and Orsten, to go at Kentucky, led by Riley and Dampier, like heavyweights, each trying for the knockout punch. FIRST ANNOUNCER (V.O. CONT’D) I have never seen anything like this! It’s like Louis and Marciano out there! The Miners SCORE AGAIN. Rupp looks at the board where the Miners are up 52-49 with 8:42 left. He calls a TIME-OUT a explodes into a tirade at his players.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: What the hell you doin’ out there?! How can you let a bunch niggers playin’ nigger ball do that to you?!!

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: (breathless) Coach, those guys can play.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: You forget what uniform you wear?! This is Kentucky basketball! Play like it!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: HASKINS... STANDS IN THE MIDDLE OF HIS PLAYERS. Though ti their dogged look says they can taste victory.  113.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Listen-- those guys don’t know what hit them, you hear me? You're faster than them. You’re stronger! You’re better! This game is yours to win! WITH MARY, THE PLAYERS PARENTS AND THE OTHER MINER FANS o one side of the arena, and the stunned Kentucky fans in t rest, the Miners take the floor for the final push. THE MINERS LIGHT UP THE SCOREBOARD. IN SLOW MOTION we see Shed go in for a flying dunk and SCORE! THE BLACK FANS are on their feet, white fans sitting stun and grim, unable to reply. IN SLOW MOTION Cager buries a spinning hook and SCORES! Worsley takes a fast break pass in for two! ALL KENTUCKY CAN DO NOW IS FOUL, and they do, sending Min after Miner to the line. Finally, Bobby Joe intercepts a Kentucky pass and holds the ball, looking up at the clock HASKINS IS LOOKING AT THE CLOCK, suspended. MARY IS IN THE CROWD, her hands to her mouth, not breathi TEN SECONDS REMAIN. The score is 71-63. Trying to wind do the clock, Hill is fouled by Riley who has played like a warrior. It is Riley's fifth and final foul. He walks off court. He passes Bobby Joe and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: Great game. You deserved it. Moved, Bobby Joe takes Riley’s hand. White hand grasping Bobby Joe watches Riley walk to the bench and Coach Rupp.

dialogues.speaker: RILEY
dialogues.text: We played Kentucky basketball, Coach. And we just got beat. Rupp looks at his great forward, in bitter silence. AT THE BENCH the white players are half off the bench, ha on their knees, ready to run into court, with Haskins hol them back. MEANWHILE, BOBBY JOE SINKS ANOTHER FREE THROW and as Kent inbounds the ball, all the white Miners, led by Armstrong RISE as one and begin to COUNT with the CLOCK.  114. ON THE KENTUCKY BENCH players sit with their heads down, tears in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MINERS
dialogues.text: Ten, nine, eight... UP IN THE STANDS, MINER fans join in, SCREAMING delirious

dialogues.speaker: MINER FANS
dialogues.text: Seven, six, five, four... Shed looks across at Armstrong, his heart BEATING like cr

dialogues.speaker: SHED
dialogues.text: We're gonna be National Champions! Mama‘s not gonna believe it! With the CLOCK ticking its FINAL SECOND, Dampier hits a meaningless JUMPER and the Miners swarm the floor.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: In the greatest upset in National Championship history, Texas Western beats the Kentucky Wildcats! The Kentucky players stand crushed. Bobby Joe LEAPS into Lattin’s arms. Shed does his trademark GIRAFFE TROT aroun the hardwood. The white players surround their black team mates with excitement. Flournoy CRUSHES Baudoin with a hu The parents in the audience are jumping up and down, hugg and screaming with joy. As the players and their parents go crazy, Haskins looks into the stands. Mary comes running down the aisle and ju into his arms. He kisses her and TWIRLS her around. Just then, Shed lifts BOBBY JOE up on his shoulders. Taki the net from the rim, he LIFTS it HIGH into the AIR, the SOUND of the CROWD’S ROAR washing over him and his teamma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman Carr is celebrating with his friends, all of them whooping and yelling, Carr in the center, looking overjoy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross cracks open a bottle of champagne and pours it over Shed’s face. Yelping, Shed pours some on Armstrong who st to sing Aretha Franklin's “RESPECT” in a Missoura drawl. Wincing at first, the black players join in just in time.  115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herman Carr is making everybody be quiet, pointing to the television image of Haskins at a press conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands with Mary at a podium, sweat drenched.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: When you put this team together, did you want to make a statement about race in America?

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Hell, no. I did it for Herman Carr.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Herman Carr? Who's he? Haskins looks at Mary a moment and then back at the repor

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: A real good basketball player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON HERMAN CARR. He sits quiet, with tears in his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don steps into the elevator. A BLACK ELEVATOR MAN smiles

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR MAN
dialogues.text: Nice game, Coach. What floor? Before he can answer, A man steps into the elevator and t a flask of whiskey from his pocket. It is a beaten, defea Adolph Rupp. Haskins looks at the elevator man.

dialogues.speaker: HASKINS
dialogues.text: Fourth. Rupp takes a hit of whiskey and stares. His voice raspy,

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: You may not know it, Coach, but basketball just changed tonight. It just passed me by. Rupp turns to Haskins. There are tears in his bloodshot e  116.

dialogues.speaker: RUPP
dialogues.text: Old men shouldn’t play boy's games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silver 707 lands and pulls up toward the control tower 30,000 fans stand waiting. The hatch of the plane opens. Cager and the other Miners appear the CROWD goes CRAZY. T CHEERS rise to DEAFENING levels as Willie Cager raises th 1966 NCAA CHAMPIONSHIP trophy up over his head. EXT. MESA STREET - EL PASO — LATER A triumphal MOTORCADE passes through El Paso, thousands o cheering fans lining the streets and waving to their hero At the head of the procession is Don, with Mary and the b at his side. Ross and Moe bring up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch El Paso explode with celebration. Cars drive the streets, HONKING their HORNS, BONFIRES are lit all over t FIREHYDRANTS are opened and water sprays everywhere as th little town that could is delirious with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the movers and shakers of El Paso are at a posh dinne celebration of Texas Western’s victory. Mary, dressed to nines in a beautiful gown, sits restlessly. Seeing Ross, pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ross, have you seen Don? He said he'd be here by seven. Ross looks at Mary quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Gee, Mary, I guess I don’t rightly know. It’s not like Don to miss an important occasion like this. Mary looks at Ross with a look that knows better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haskins stands at the foul line in tux and bow tie. He lo up at the basket, flips up a free throw and... ...-hits nothing but net. FADE OUT.  117.

dialogues.speaker: OVER A BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: DON “THE BEAR” HASKINS turned down offers to coach in the NBA, remaining loyal to the Miners. He has led the Miners to 1 NCAA tournaments, won 7 WAC titles and accrued over 719 victories. In 1997 he was elected into the Basketball Hall of Fame.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (BIG DADDY)
dialogues.text: became a first-round NBA pick. Now a successful businessm he gives motivational speeches around the country.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE CAGER
dialogues.text: suffered several strokes in the years following the Texas Western victory. His charitable basketball foundation now helps underprivileged students are thinking of quitting school.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY JOE HILL
dialogues.text: married Tina Malichi and lived in El Paso until his death in the winter of 2002. Over ten thousand El Pasoans attended his funeral.

dialogues.speaker: PAT RILEY
dialogues.text: went on to coach the “Los Angeles Lakers” to four World Championships. He has since coached the “Ne York Knicks” and the “Miami Heat”.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLPH RUPP
dialogues.text: finally recruited the first black player in Kentucky's history before stepping down from Kentucky Basketball in 1972, having won a record 876 game Even with all his achievements, he never got over the loss to Texas Western. Years after Rupp’s retirement, Tuby Smith became the firs black Kentucky coach to lead an all black Kentucky team to the National Championship. The Texas Western victory over Kentucky has been called t most important game in the history of College Basketball one of the greatest sports upsets of the century.
